story:
SHOW YOUR SUPPORT for the LAUNCH OF THE FIRST NOT-FOR-PROFIT CROWDSOURCED DESIGN PLATFORM FOR EMERGING CREATIVES AGED BETWEEN 16-28 YRS.

Pitchtous.net connects businesses looking for design work with young creatives from around the world. All profits generated go back into MENTORING, INTERNSHIP, SCHOLARSHIP and PERSONAL PROJECT FUNDING opportunities for our young creatives members.

//.

Foreword by A.CE - London street artist & Pitchtous.net Patron

A.CE is a London based artist. He has been an active part of the UK street art scene for over 10 years. In that time his wheat-pasted images have featured prominently across the urban landscape.

"I am an advocate for young, untapped raw creative talent, and I believe companies, brands and organisations have much to benefit. Pitchtous is a great idea. It makes complete business sense and stands to benefit all involved, not least the young artists and designers whose careers will flourish with the right opportunities, support and encouragement and it gives me great pleasure to offer my support and be a patron of such an organisation." by A.CE

//.

WELCOME TO THE PITCHTOUS.NET LAUNCH FUNDRAISER.

Pitchtous.net is the world’s first not-for-profit crowdsourced design platform. Creatives submit design solutions in response to design brief's set by businesses and the winning creative receives a cash payment for their work.

Pitchtous Ltd is a registered not-for-profit company (UK Reg No: 8738900).

//.

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT?

Pitchtous is a genuine indie start-up. Over the past year, founder Alx Gunn has pooled money from savings, family and friends to develop and build a very lo-fi, web-platform, she's gathered interest from young designers and businesses from across the globe, as well as patrons and advisors that will be key to it's growth, but now she needs help funding the support it's official launch.

//.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

Here’s how you can help and be a part of something amazing - the creative youth revolution. All we’re asking for is your support and in return we’ve got some great perks lined up, so go check them out and see what you could contribute.

//.

COMPLETE LIST OF PERKS

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

***** STAR PERKS FROM LONDON STREET ARTIST - A.CE *****

A.CE is a London based artist. He has been an active part of the UK street art scene for over 10 years. In that time his wheat-pasted images have featured prominently across the urban landscape. Born in London in 1980, A.CE’s works act as an outlet for the wide and varied influences that have inspired him throughout his life, drawing in part from Dada collage and classic pop art to his time as a skateboarder and the bold graphics and artworks he encountered during this time. His work is a raw presentation of nostalgic imagery blended with contemporary fragments, resulting in ambiguities and incongruities that reflect the absurdities of popular culture and a consumer driven society.

//.

A.CE PERK NO.1

4x A3 1988 RISO PRINTS, by - A.CE 

GET YOUR HANDS ON YOUR VERY OWN A3 RISO PRINT, by A.CE. Limited Edition of 100, signed, numbered and embossed by A.CE himself. Numbers: 16, 17, 18, 19 // 100. These are simply stunning, vibrant pieces. ONLY £25.00 EACH!

     

//.

A.CE PERK NO.2

5 x A1 SIGNED WHEAT 'PASTE-UPS' by  A.CE. THIS IS THE THE REAL DEAL!  GET YOUR HANDS ON AN ORIGINAL A1 RARE SIGNED ARTIST/STUDIO PRINTED STREET READY PASTE-UP / ORIGINAL VARIANT ON PAPER.

If there are folds in the paper, this is simply due to the work being folded and taken on a paste-up mission, but didn't make it up, so are truely authentic street pieces.

These are originals on paper, variants on paper, artist quality, not just from a standard editioned print run. Check out A.CE at work: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M44VTYq0wks&feature=youtu.be

VARIOUS DESIGNS TO CHOOSE FROM, (Please clearly indicate which print you'd like when you order) £280.00 Each. FREE SHIPPING.

  

1x 50'S FACE. ONE COLOUR RARE SIGNED ARTIST/STUDIO PRINTED STREET READY PASTE-UP / ORIGINAL VARIANT ON PAPER. £280. FREE SHIPPING.

story_txt:
SHOW YOUR SUPPORT for the LAUNCH OF THE FIRST NOT-FOR-PROFIT CROWDSOURCED DESIGN PLATFORM FOR EMERGING CREATIVES AGED BETWEEN 16-28 YRS. 
Pitchtous.net connects
businesses looking for design work with young creatives from around the world. All profits generated go back into MENTORING, INTERNSHIP, SCHOLARSHIP and PERSONAL PROJECT FUNDING opportunities for our young
creatives members.//.Foreword by A.CE - London street artist & Pitchtous.net PatronA.CE is a London based artist. He
has been an active part of the UK street art scene for over 10 years. In that
time his wheat-pasted images have featured prominently across the urban
landscape.
"I am an advocate for young, untapped raw creative talent, and I believe
companies, brands and organisations have much to benefit. Pitchtous is a great
idea. It makes complete business sense and stands to benefit all involved, not
least the young artists and designers whose careers will flourish with the
right opportunities, support and encouragement and it gives me great pleasure to offer my support and be a patron of such
an organisation." by A.CE//.WELCOME TO THE PITCHTOUS.NET LAUNCH FUNDRAISER.
Pitchtous.net is the world’s
first not-for-profit crowdsourced design platform. Creatives submit design solutions in response to design brief's set by
businesses and the winning creative receives a cash payment for their work.
Pitchtous Ltd is a
registered not-for-profit company (UK Reg No: 8738900).
 
//.WHY DO WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT? Pitchtous is a genuine indie start-up. Over the past year, founder Alx Gunn has pooled money from savings, family and friends to develop and build a very lo-fi, web-platform, she's gathered interest from young designers and businesses from across the globe, as well as patrons and advisors that will be key to it's growth, but now she needs help funding the support it's official launch. //.
HOW CAN YOU HELP? Here’s how you can help and be a part of
something amazing - the creative youth revolution. All we’re asking for is your
support and in return we’ve got some great perks lined up, so go check them out
and see what you could contribute.//.COMPLETE LIST OF PERKS
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
***** STAR PERKS FROM LONDON STREET ARTIST - A.CE *****
A.CE is a London based artist. He has been an active part of the UK street
art scene for over 10 years. In that time his wheat-pasted images have featured
prominently across the urban landscape. Born in London in 1980, A.CE’s works
act as an outlet for the wide and varied influences that have inspired him
throughout his life, drawing in part from Dada collage and classic pop art to
his time as a skateboarder and the bold graphics and artworks he encountered during
this time. His work is a raw presentation of nostalgic imagery blended with contemporary
fragments, resulting in ambiguities and incongruities that reflect the
absurdities of popular culture and a consumer driven society.//.A.CE PERK NO.14x A3 1988 RISO PRINTS, by - A.CE  
GET YOUR HANDS ON YOUR VERY OWN A3 RISO PRINT, by A.CE. Limited Edition of 100, signed, numbered and embossed by A.CE
himself. Numbers: 16, 17, 18, 19 // 100. These are simply stunning, vibrant pieces. ONLY £25.00 EACH!

being folded and taken on a paste-up mission, but didn't 
make it up, so are truely authentic street pieces.These are originals on paper, variants on paper, artist quality, not just from a standard editioned print run. story:
Hi! My name is Xochilt Hernandez, I'm nicaraguan and I really love teaching.  Though I started as an anthropologist teaching anthropology courses, I have come to see in education  not only the force that makes us grow closer to ourselves, and our communities, but also to others, to those who are different from us; creating community by the collective sharing of knowlege and experience. So, this is what I want to dedicate my life to.

Now, on that road, I have been given the opportunity to teach in the Mostar Summer Youth Program in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina this summer (June 18th-July 13th), developing courses based on intercultural understanding, social innovation and leadership.

However, I don't have the funds to pay for the ticket to travel there. I've never been good at asking, but this time I know I do need help.  I really want to go. I want to experience the opportunity to design my own courses in a different educational context and gain the teaching experience while learning from young bosnians and the MSYP staff.

Please help me raise the US$2,700 to pay for my airplane ticket from Managua to Sarajevo. Please help me go to Mostar and share with the MSYP students everything I've learned so far, while I also keep learning from them to become a better teacher. ¡Muchas gracias!

story:
What is this project?

My name is Piia Wirsu and last Saturday I was in Kathmandu for the 7.6 magnitude earthquake which hit Nepal. Since that time I have spoken to many people, all of which have a story to tell which involves some tragedy. In the rural districts of Nepal many villages have been completely wiped out and there is a desperate need for food, clothing, medicine and, in time, rebuilding. This project is designed to raise funds to address these needs. There are so many districts of Nepal which need help and the wish to be able to provide funds to everyone, though sincere, is not realistic so this project is focusing on one or two remote villages in Gorkha district. I have a friend who's family is from this area and that is why I have chosen to direct these efforts here. 

Initially donations will go towards ensuring all basic needs are met, that locals have food, water, clothing and shelter. Once this is achieved funds will be directed towards clean up and rebuilding. Food, water and clothing will be purchased and transported to this village to ensure all donations go directly towards helping those in the village and no money is lost in administration fees or is misdirected. All work for this project is being conducted voluntarily. Materials for building homes can be sourced locally and for free in the district, however money is needed to employ labourers to source the materials and then build. 


Why donate here? 

A story I have heard again and again speaking to locals while in Nepal is that countries keep promising aid but it never seems to reach those who need it most. As one person put it, "it feeds the stomach of the government here". Any donation made to this project will go 100% towards helping those who need it, there are no administration costs or bureaucracy which can absorb the funds. 


Why am I doing this?

After the earthquake I was overwhelmed by the generosity and caring of those around me, although many people have lost houses, family and friends the Nepalese people that I interacted with always ensured I had food, water and a place to take shelter. I slept alongside locals for three nights in the open following the earthquake and was made to feel like an adopted relative of those families around me. I would like to return the goodwill which was shown to me and my contacts in the Ghorka region allow me to provide aid relief there. Your donation will help me do this. 


How will your donation be managed?

Your donation will be managed and budgeted to ensure the maximum can be pulled from each dollar. Funds in Nepal will be managed by Sandesh Tamang who has experience in working within budgets and accounting for spending. Sandesh has worked as an expedition sirdar in charge of trip finances for many years and is a trusted friend who can act as the Nepal link to ensure assistance is given to those who most need it. 


How much do we need?

I aim to raise $1000 dollars, although any more would only help to provide ongoing support. My concern is that once the news dies down and people forget about what happened the people of Nepal will find that aid falls away also. This is a time when they will need just as much if not more as they struggle with food shortages and the mammoth effort of cleaning up and rebuilding. I would love you to help me continue to provide support after the memories have faded by donating anything you can to help me reach or exceed this target. If the target is not reached the money will still be directed as detailed above. 


What do you get for your donation? 

A personal thank you card so you know your donation is appreciated and you can follow the progress of the project on www.facebook.com/tasnepalrebuild


A final note

Any assistance you can provide would be greatly appreciated, not just by me but by those who receive the support from it. Giving is all the more rewarding when given to those who expect nothing. Even if you can only spare a dollar, please donate, it takes us a step closer to our goal.

If you are unable to give that is okay, we all have expenses, but please pass on this project to others who may be able to donate, share and help to build the momentum through which great things can happen! I have been shown in the 72 hours since the earthquake that disaster also provides the opportunity for great humanity and generosity of spirit to surface, please help to return this spirit, any help is met with gratitude.

story:
Our story

 

We are Artur and Phillipi and we are moved by one question: What if everybody could made of their work an expression of who they really are? Actually, no, we know the answer to that: the World would be much much better. Can you imagine? People going to work happy in the mornings? We are thrilled with this image. That's why we started Become, to answer the next big question: How?

 

Together, we created a model to help people design the life they want to live after they have enough self-awareness to craft that. The steps are:

Get to know yourself

Own and fall in love for your own story

Explore the possibilities

Decide on a path

Create an Action Plan

Bonus: Prepare for detours (because we all know how life enjoys surprising us)

 

Each block comprises a set of questions and exercises extensively tested and perfected to help you reach a more fulfilling and happy way of design your career.

The model can take the shape of a online course, a series of workshops, a weekend retreat and, even, an mobile app. And this is exactly the order we want to pursue so we can, step by step, reach more and more people.

 

That's why you're reading this: to help us start faster.

 

What is the goal of the campaign?

 

We do have the model, but to turn it into real products/services we need to invest on video making, material, web design and hosting, besides the initial investments to establish the company. Besides that, we want to have our own office where we can host the workshops and on-site courses. Altogether, we aim to reach 15 000 euros.

 

Which are the risks?

 

The initial risks are mainly related to not selling enough to keep us afloat. To avoid that we have created a diversified marketing plan that include producing good content, a series of free events to build a network and some free tools that will be available on our webpage. More important than that, what we know will make the difference is the community we want to build around Become. Because the hardest part comes afterward, when people set to live their own journey. For that we design a strategy to keep our people connected and supporting each other, as well, as offering resources to guide them. This way, we expect to keep clients engaged and build momentum around our mission.

 

Other ways you can help

 

Maybe you can't donate, but we are sure you just fell in love for the idea as much as us, right? So if you can spread the word, share this campaign with more people, it would be great.

Also, we need a lot of help with web and graphic design. Besides, if you have legal knowledge and you are based in Spain, you could help us immensely.

 

Thank you so very much to come till here and help us as you can, donating, sharing it, etc. We both thank you a lot.

story:
Our Campaign

Hi friends, family and the community as a whole! Meals that Matter is made up of 4 college students that attend the University of Tennessee. We are working together with the Boys and Girls Clubs of the Tennessee Valley, BGCTNV, to raise money for meals for the students that are a part of this organization.This is important to us because not only do we care about bettering our community, but we want to give these kids successful futures and healthy lifestyles. The money donated goes directly to the kids and it will make a much bigger impact on them than it will to give up 3 of your dollar bills!

What We Need & What You'll Get

It takes about $3 a day for them to feed a child at their club. Our starting goal is to raise $1000, totaling to feeding 333 kids per day. BGCTNV serve around 1500 kids a day, so going over the goal of $1000 will just mean that extra money will go toward feeding even more kids. A simple $3 donation can feed a kid for an entire day-and imagine how much we can grow on that. 

The Impact

If we do not reach our goal of $1000, all the money donated will still go to feeding the kids-so really it’s just the more the merrier! Any little or big donation can go a long way! This campaign is meant to be as open and as trustworthy as possible. We aim to allow you to see exactly where your money is going and who it is affecting. This isn't just another campaign for an organization that never happens or that just raises a little and stops there-we want to make a huge impact on this organization. We want to provide as many meals as possible-and we cannot do it without your help! The money that is donated will go directly to meals for kids, which are crucial to their health and their well-being. This organization does so much to build good citizens, provide them with academic success and better futures. The more meals provided means more kids with brighter futures. 

Spread the Word

Even if you aren't able to donate to our campaign, we would love for you to share this and get the word out to anyone that you know! Like we said, any small donation can help-and even sharing this on Facebook can too! Just use the simple Indiegogo share tools and that’s all there is to it!

 

Thanks so much for your time and support! Meals that Matter and The Boys and Girls Clubs of the Tennessee Valley thanks you!!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
NOTE: I will consider the money I will raise in this campaign a loan that I will commit myself to repay by investing the same amount in educating the ideals of objective journalism and free press in Egypt.



What I Need 

Tourism has collapsed in Egypt due to our three-year turmoil, hurting my family’s shop in a tourist market. I also live in a society where people do not pay that much for college, and I have little savings that would allow me to cover my living expenses.

I need a total of $14,000;  $2000 for books, $2780 for transportation, $6000 for Other expenses ( food, utilities, equipment, cell..etc), $3100  for heath insurance  and $290 for activity fee. 

Samples of my Photos 

 A river of blood flows down a street Monday in Cairo, Egypt, where supporters of ousted President Mohammed Morsi clashed with the military, killing more than 50 people and injuring hundreds. AMINA ISMAIL/MCT

A solider stands guard Monday, Nov. 18, 2013 near Tahrir Square in Cairo, Egypt at a memorial to those killed two years ago in clashes with security forces. Then protesters were demanding an Egypt no longer governed by the military. (Amina Ismail/MCT)

Al Jazeera English correspondent Peter Greste, Al Jazeera English bureau chief Mohamed Fahmy, and cameraman Baher Mohamed, stand in cage in an Egyptian court room. The three journalists are accused of falsifying news about Egypt and running a terror cell.

Samples Of My Work 

  • http://www.mcclatchydc.com/search_results?q=Amina+Ismail

  • http://www.pbs.org/wnet/need-to-know/video/video-egypt-now/13191/

  • http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2011/aug/18/egypt-who-calls-shots/

  • http://www.egyptindependent.com//staff/amina-ismail

  • http://www.marketwatch.com/story/al-jazeera-journalists-sentenced-to-7-years-in-egypt-jails-2014-06-23

  • http://online.wsj.com/search/term.html?KEYWORDS=Amina%20Ismail


My Story 

What I remember most about my childhood is the patina of fear that hung over every experience. Under former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Egyptians were not allowed to question the government, let alone criticize it. An opaque system of governance built on fear; we never knew what could get us thrown in jail or branded as enemies of the state. Such fear permeated every childhood experience so much so that I think my interest in journalism was born out of an outrage about that fear and a deep desire to break it.

Indeed of my five siblings, I, the second born, was considered the family rebel. Where my parents urged us to keep quiet, I insisted on pushing the limits of both family and my country. I would express my frustration with the daily ills of Egypt, and the government’s unwillingness to address them. Yet when I so much as  mentioned the name of Mubarak, my father would bounce from his seat, grab all the phones and hide them under the cushions.  Looking at all of us, he would whisper, “Even if the phones are switched off, they can hear us.”

This was my Egypt, a nation full of rules and bureaucracy that didn’t make sense, that didn’t advance the lives of Egyptians. Throughout Mubarak’s tenure, where the quality of life improved for an elite few, for the majority life around them was deteriorating – in the schools, public health, housing, the roads and the like.

That one could not even acknowledge the decay before us was unacceptable to me, so much so I used to protest in school against government practices for years, leading to my suspension. I didn’t realize it at the time but even then I was a journalist, confident in the power of speaking out and reporting the truth.

The Egypt that only provided for a few played out on a national stage and in my everyday experiences. “You are a girl, you can’t do this,” I frequently heard. At schools, the boys played on the bigger playground and took better school trips. At home, my father often rejected my pleas to try something new, saying, “My girls don’t do such things. When you get married, your husband can decide.”

My first story in 2008 was covering a strike led by government opponents trying to seek change. I had to sneak out of the house to bypass my parents who urged me not to attend.  I came back that night and told them what I had done and seen, in the hopes that it would break the wall of fear that had defined their generation.

Given such experiences, I wonder if it was not inevitable that my generation would no longer accept such norms. Through the Internet we were exposed to a world very different from that which our parents knew. Upon the 2011 uprising that led to Mubarak’s fall, the old Egypt was confronted with a new reality.

To break the shackles of fear is itself a form of liberation, I believe. No longer in fear of what the switched off phones may capture, I now ask the questions that once lingered in my mind to both Egyptians and Americans alike. In April 2013, I attended a White House briefing just days after the Boston bombing. As press spokesman Jay Carney repeatedly dodged journalists’ questions, one kept coming up in my mind. The White House called what happened at the end of the Boston marathon an act of terror, citing that a child was among the dead. But what about the death of children in places like Afghanistan at the hands of U.S. drone operators? Was that too a form of terrorism, I wondered.

So I asked Carney, and our exchange caused a national stir. For me, the girl of parents who spent their lives in fear, the experience was ultimately a breakthrough. I am part of a new generation that knows that only through speaking out, whether at home or on the street or at the White House, can a life of fear subside.

Amina Ismail To Jay Carney: Are U.S. Bombings That Kill Afghan Civilians 'A Form Of Terrorism'?

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/18/amina-ismail-jay-carney_n_3110760.html 


I was also featured in Viomundo, a Brazilian news organization. 

Other Ways You Can Help

A donation in any amount will be very well appreciated and will definitely help me earn my master's degree. If you can't pay, there are still many other ways you can help with. Spread the word to your friends and family about my campaign via facebook, twitter, emails and any other means of communication.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/18/amina-ismail-jay-carney_n_3110760.html

Other Ways You Can Help


A donation in any amount will be very well appreciated and will definitely help me earn my master's degree. If you can't pay, there are still many other ways you can help with. Spread the word to your friends and family about my campaign via facebook, twitter, emails and any other means of communication.

story:
ESPAÑOL:

El colegio San Juancito Medio  se encuentra en la región del Urabá antioqueño,  una  zona rural aislada de Colombia  que ha sido  golpeada por la violencia y la pobreza.

En San Juancito estudian  185 estudiantes desde preescolar hasta la educación básica secundaria. La escuela la ha  construido  la comunidad; las aulas no están terminadas y la mayoría  están al aire libre.

Los estudiantes  enfrentan condiciones difíciles para  llegar al colegio,  la mayoría de ellos caminan una o dos horas por caminos en mal estado.  Una vez allí,  los niños  no encuentran el espacio apropiado para aprender; no hay aulas delimitadas, no hay agua potable y no hay  biblioteca.

Somos un grupo de profesores de una  comunidad  llamada Enseña por Colombia; hemos estado trabajando en el colegio San Juancito desde enero de 2014. Queremos que estos niños tengan las mejores condiciones para el aprendizaje y  sean más competitivos. Nuestro objetivo es  mejorar sus habilidades académicas y que tengan las mismas oportunidades  que los demás estudiantes del país.

El año pasado, la escuela recibió computadores, libros y conexión a Internet después de una larga espera. Creemos  que la biblioteca es necesaria  porque nos permitirá   utilizar eficazmente los nuevos recursos existentes. El proyecto de construcción de la biblioteca está estancado porque desafortunadamente la  comunidad  no tienen más recursos para continuar su  construcción. Mientras tanto los niños ven impotentes  cómo los pocos libros se están deteriorando.

Según la pruebas PISA (Programa para la Evaluación Internacional de Alumnos por sus siglas en inglés), Colombia ocupa  los últimos lugares, lo cual pone en evidencia la baja calidad de la educación. Creemos que una de las principales causas es la falta de infraestructura en las escuelas rurales de Colombia; la ausencia de recursos físicos definitivamente incide de una manera negativa en el aprendizaje.

Para que esto sea posible necesitamos materiales de construcción tales como cemento, arena, ladrillos, estuco, barras de hierro, puntillas, madera, estantes de libros, mesas, sillas ¡y mucho más!

¡Todos son bienvenidos a nuestro colegio!


ENGLISH;

San Juancito school is located in Urabá region, an isolated rural area hit by violence and poverty in Colombia.

There are 185 students from preschool to secondary basic education. The school is being built by the community and the classrooms are in the open air. 

The students also face difficult conditions to finally arrive to school, most of them walk one or two hours through poor roads, once they get there, they don´t find the most appropriate space to learn; no delimited classrooms, no clean drinking water and no library.

We are a group of teachers. We are part of an education community called Enseña por Colombia (Teach for Colombia) and we have been working in the school since January 2014. We want to support them, we want them  to be competitive and improve their academical skills and  have equal opportunities compare to other students in the country. 

Last year the school received computers, books and connection to internet after a long wait,  we think that the library is necessary in order to use effectively the existing resources . The library building project is stalled because the community don´t have more resources to continue. Meanwhile kids are watching helplessness how the very few books are deteriorating.

According to PISA (Program for International Student Assessment), Colombia ranks in the lowest level. We think one of the main causes is the lack of infrastructure in Colombian rural schools; the absence of physical resources could negatively affect learning.

To make this possible we need constructions material such as concrete, sand, bricks, stucco, iron bars, nails, wood, book shelves, tables, chairs and much more! .

Feel free if you want to visit us! 

GRACIAS /THANK YOU / MERCI/ DANKE

story:
Short Summary

Makarios Community School will be launching a non-profit democratic free school for Kindergarten through 12th grade in the greater DFW area Fall 2015.

  • We currently have roughly 20 families and 30 students ready to enroll after just one month of marketing. We'd like to project growth to 100-150 students.
  • At Makarios Community School students gain 13 years* of living passionately and learn the value of doing the things they love most. *Students who attend K-12 grade.
  • Our core values: Free to Learn According to Interest & Ability , Cooperative Learning, Character Development, Positive Conflict Resolution, Democratic Community Decision Making and Family Support.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Fixed Costs:  Property payment, Insurance
  • Variable Costs: Utilities, staff, supplies, miscellaneous projects
  • We'd like to open our school to as many students as possible. Having a diverse conglomerate of students adds to the character and effectiveness of a school. Your help would aid our flexible tuition program and provide funds in order to sustain our exceptional staff.
  • You get the satisfaction of participating in the education revolution!  Makarios Community School will be the first democratic free school in the DFW area. Thanks for helping us make this a reality!

The Impact

The education bubble we have is about to burst. The manufacturing of individuals is going to end soon. The type of education we had in the past was to prepare people for a stagnant society. We all know that our society is moving at a faster pace than ever. The type of individuals we need in this day and age is one who is self-driven, an independent learner, and extremely adaptable.  According to research, the democratic free school model produces these types of learners.

Risks & Challenges

As a very non-traditional school, there is a lot of apprehension when it comes to our philosophy.   However, stories of democratic free school alumni demonstrates this pedagogy not only works, but is very effective in producing young people who know how to lead, are self-motivated and passionate about learning.  The most prominent democratic free school models are Summerhill (1921) in England, Albany Free School (1969) in New York and Sudbury Valley (1968) in Massachusetts. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Support us on social media!

  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/makarioscommunityschool?ref=br_tf
  • Twitter: https://twitter.com/MakariosSchool
  • Website: http://www.makarioscommunityschool.org
Watch a movie!! Being informed and gaining knowledgeable about the different educational options for families is invaluable to the future of education.
  • Summerhill (2008) is an entertaining 90 minute docudrama that shares the vision of the longest operating democratic free school.
  • Changing Education Paradigms - This RSA Animate was adapted from a talk given at the RSA by Sir Ken Robinson, world-renowned education and creativity expert and recipient of the RSA's Benjamin Franklin award

The Team

Aaron Yang


This is what I've always dreamed of being a part of; a school where I can breathe freely. When I was a student at Texas A&M, I first discovered an article talking about the Sudbury Valley School in Framingham, Massachusetts. I first though it was a bizarre concept and wondered if the students actually learned. After graduating with my degree in Applied Mathematics, I thought to myself, "What have I really learned?"  Well, I've got some pretty legit calculus skills…

School has taught me to follow directions, gain the adoration of my superiors, give the correct answers, but nothing about how to live life. It dawned on me that I was being crafted into another piece for the machine of society. While some may be comfortable with this notion, I decided that I wanted to shape my life through my decisions. The gift of life is precious, many of us go through life without realizing how valuable it is. We often let other people dictate what we do with our most precious thing. Wield it and harness it to its fullest potential.

As part of the leadership team at Makarios Community School, I am most excited to create a haven where every member has the room and space to breathe freely. In this space, students will be able to grow to be strong adaptable individuals capable of being self-driven towards what ever goal they desire.


Donella Cecrle

In January 2011 I heard a NPR program about Brooklyn Free School and I was intrigued.  I wished I could have gone to a school like that and wanted to ensure that my children had the opportunity to enjoy interested directed learning. I began reading about various free and democratic schools, visiting campuses and talking to others that are interested in alternative methods of education. Over the past year, my children and I have participated in a democratic free learning co-op with other home education families.  It has been a fun and rewarding experience.  I am really looking forward to having a campus where students may enjoy this style of learning on a daily basis!  

Makarios Community School is sponsored by Makarios Ministries, Inc. a non-profit advocacy organization that exist to support the community through programs and partnerships.  Makarios Community School has no religious affiliation and will be open to all students and their families that value alternative democratic education.
story_txt:
Short Summary Makarios Community School will be launching a non-profit democratic free school for Kindergarten through 12th grade in the greater DFW area Fall 2015.  We currently have roughly 20 families and 30 students ready to enroll after just one month of marketing. We'd like to project growth to 100-150 students. At Makarios Community School students gain 13 years* of living passionately and learn the value of doing the things they love most. *Students who attend K-12 grade. Our core values: Free to Learn According to Interest & Ability , Cooperative Learning, Character Development, Positive Conflict Resolution, Democratic Community Decision Making and Family Support.
   What We Need & What You Get 
Fixed Costs:  Property payment, Insurance
Variable Costs: Utilities, staff, supplies, miscellaneous projects We'd like to open our school to as many students as possible. Having a diverse conglomerate of students adds to the character and effectiveness of a school. Your help would aid our flexible tuition program and provide funds in order to sustain our exceptional staff.
You get the satisfaction of participating in the education revolution!  Makarios Community School will be the first democratic free school in the DFW area. Thanks for helping us make this a reality!    The Impact
The education bubble we have is about to burst. The manufacturing of individuals is going to end soon. The type of education we had in the past was to prepare people for a stagnant society. We all know that our society is moving at a faster pace than ever. The type of individuals we need in this day and age is one who is self-driven, an independent learner, and extremely adaptable.  According to research, the democratic free school model produces these types of learners.   Risks & Challenges As a very non-traditional school, there is a lot of apprehension when it comes to our philosophy.   However, stories of democratic free school alumni demonstrates this pedagogy not only works, but is very effective in producing young people who know how to lead, are self-motivated and passionate about learning.  The most prominent democratic free school models are Summerhill (1921) in England, Albany Free School (1969) in New York and Sudbury Valley (1968) in Massachusetts.    Other Ways You Can Help Support us on social media!  Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/makarioscommunityschool?ref=br_tf

Twitter: https://twitter.com/MakariosSchool


Website: http://www.makarioscommunityschool.org
 
Watch a movie!! Being informed and gaining knowledgeable about the different educational options for families is invaluable to the future of education.


Summerhill (2008) is an entertaining 90 minute docudrama that shares the vision of the longest operating democratic free school.

Changing Education Paradigms - This RSA Animate was adapted from a talk given at the RSA by Sir Ken Robinson, world-renowned education and creativity expert and recipient of the RSA's Benjamin Franklin award
  The TeamAaron Yang



This is what I've always dreamed of being a part of; a school where I can breathe freely. When I was a student at Texas A&M, I first discovered an article talking about the Sudbury Valley School in Framingham, Massachusetts. I first though it was a bizarre concept and wondered if the students actually learned. After graduating with my degree in Applied Mathematics, I thought to myself, "What have I really learned?"  Well, I've got some pretty legit calculus skills…
School has taught me to follow directions, gain the adoration of my superiors, give the correct answers, but nothing about how to live life. It dawned on me that I was being crafted into another piece for the machine of society. While some may be comfortable with this notion, I decided that I wanted to shape my life through my decisions. The gift of life is precious, many of us go through life without realizing how valuable it is. We often let other people dictate what we do with our most precious thing. Wield it and harness it to its fullest potential.
As part of the leadership team at Makarios Community School, I am most excited to create a haven where every member has the room and space to breathe freely. In this space, students will be able to grow to be strong adaptable individuals capable of being self-driven towards what ever goal they desire.

Donella Cecrle

In January 2011 I heard a NPR program about Brooklyn Free School and I was intrigued.  I wished I could have gone to a school like that and wanted to ensure that my children had the opportunity to enjoy interested directed learning. I began reading about various free and democratic schools, visiting campuses and talking to others that are interested in alternative methods of education. Over the past year, my children and I have participated in a democratic free learning co-op with other home education families.  It has been a fun and rewarding experience.  I am really looking forward to having a campus where students may enjoy this style of learning on a daily basis!  
Makarios Community School is sponsored by Makarios Ministries, Inc. a non-profit advocacy organization that exist to support the community through programs and partnerships.  Makarios Community School has no religious affiliation and will be open to all students and their families that value alternative democratic education.

story:
Our Story

The WCE, (Wolff Center for Entrepreneurship) at the University of Houston’s C.T. Bauer College of Business guides students in building their dreams through entrepreneurship. The WCE not only teaches the business fundamentals that are crucial to being an entrepreneur, but also the life skills and personal growth that nurtures success.Through an event called Wolffest, these aspiring entrepreneurs get the opportunity to raise money for their undergraduate program to continue education while applying classroom knowledge.

Our Goals
The goal of Wolffest is to teach entrepreneurship students how to fund, start and run a successful business where profits fuel help develop the Wolff Center Program
Each team is judged on two criteria: capital raised and number of sales generated the day of Wolffest. Besides the learning experience, our ultimate goal is to win this competition and with your contribution- we are one step closer to the finish line.
In addition to learn about entrepreneurship, the event helps fund the various activities that the Wolff Center takes part in, Examples of activities include the Prison Entrepreneurship Program, where students help advice prisoners who hope to start business upon release, or for the many business plan competitions that our senior teams compete at.


Wolffest 2015

The students of the Wolff Center for Entrepreneurship will be putting on this food festival & fundraiser April 7-9, 2015 from 8am to 5pm daily, at the University of Houston. Students from all over campus as well as alumni and other guests will flock to Butler Plaza to experience food, entertainment and a celebration of entrepreneurship. 


Impact

The Wolff Center for Entrepreneurship is building the future of business through its comprehensive curriculum. Students like us spend time each semester not only learning from the best, but also giving back to the community through a variety of outreach programs. The Wolff Center for Entrepreneurship is a 501(c)(3) organization.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute, you can still help us out by promoting us via our Indiegogo and social media, or visit the Saint Cougar booth at Wolffest on the University of Houston campus!

story:
Short Summary

Why just graduating is not enough.

1.8 million U.S. students are expected to earn their Bachelor’s degree by the spring of 2014. Depending on the major chosen, they are facing between a five to 15 percent unemployment rate. That rate on average is 7.9 percent for all graduates according to Georgetown Public Policy Institute’s report: Hard Times, College Majors, Unemployment and Earnings (May 2013). Even more disturbing is the 36 percent mal-employment rate. More than a third of recent college graduates are working in positions that don’t require a degree says the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University.

For too many, degree-attainment’s cold hard outcome is unemployment, underemployment and rising student-loan default, hitting students-of-color especially hard. We're leveraging international field-study, helping graduates stand-out in the marketplace by targeting the public health profession. There's and need for a more global public health professional as well as an overall shortage to day and projected for 2020 according to Association of Schools of Public Health (ASPH).

In May 2014, IERCEF’s introducing a new model for education abroad. With our partner, a renowned specialist in custom study abroad programming: IES Abroad, we are launching an in-depth, Public Health in Jamaica pilot. The four-week, five credit program will give students who are already majoring or interested in pursuing public health studies a true window into how this growing profession's work gets done from a policy maker's and practitioner’s viewpoint,  (http://www.prweb.com/releases/iesabroad/hbcus/prweb9912310.htm). It will be marketed through the North Carolina Study Abroad/Global Engagement (NC SAGE) Partnership platform (http://www.prlog.org/11321516-african-americans-study-abroad-and-degree-attainment-linked.html), a collaborative of higher education institutions representing up to 42,000 students of that state’s Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). The benefit of the SAGE Partnership is that it’s a cost-effective platform for the students of under-resourced colleges to access innovative international programs that can give them a competitive edge.

I am Steven Jones: founder, president and CEO of IERC Education Foundation (IERCEF), the only social enterprise with a plan and platform to expand career-targeted, education abroad experiences for U.S. college students. I have a particular interest in the 40 percent who are first-generation college, many of whom attend Minority Serving Institutions. Consider this: out of the 283,332 college students that studied abroad in academic year 2012/13, 62 percent of them made up 76.4 percent of the students going abroad. They were White. In contrast, for African Americans who are 15 percent of those enrolled in college, they were only 5.3 percent of those studying abroad. Latinos are 16 percent of college enrollment, but 7.6 of students who earned some credits internationally. Given our increasingly global marketplace and the acknowledge demographic shifts in our nation, who has the edge? Who is more vulnerable in a global marketplace and what will correct for workplace imbalance? The solution to these questions is IERCEF's focus.

I have worked in diverse industries from marketing financial derivatives, where I traveled abroad and saw some of the globalization underway in the early 1990s to teaching high school economics and U.S. history. I have a BA (Hampshire College) and a MS (University of Delaware). Teaching in an independent and then public high school, till establishing IERCEF in 2009, is when I discovered that these two distinctly different communities were not focusing on globalization’s bigger implications as it impacted competition on all levels. I wondered if colleges were different.

48 years of improved college access policy has had a big impact. Today, over 21 million U.S. students are enrolled at nearly 5,000 colleges, 66 percent attending four-year institutions. The world comes to America for higher education. Yet, nearly two million U.S. college students graduate every year and 36 percent are mal-employed, up to 15 percent are unemployed and default on their federal student loans as the debt-burden rises. Traditionally, not enough attention has been paid to increasing global learning experiences for U.S. college students which will make them more marketable, innovative and productive in the workforce. Just graduating from college is not enough.


What We Need

To launch, $26,980 covering December - March operating expenses. We are seeking $4,000 now for immediate expenses like the completion of the SAGE Partnership webpage which will also process online applications. The IES Abroad/SAGE Partnership Public Health in Jamaica program begins and ends, May 29th to June 26th 2014.

Phase 1 Budget:

Recruitment  (17 hrs/per wk. x 9)                    $4,590

Marketing (12 hrs/per wk. x 12)                       $4,320

Application processing (30 hrs/per wk x 8)      $7,200

Fundraising (in NC)                                         $1,500

Webpage                                                        $4,000

Student support (14 hrs/per wk. x 6)                $2,520

Travel to and within NC                                      $850

Contingency (@ 8% of budget)                       $2,000

Total                                                              $26,980


Who’s in charge?

Earl M. Brown, Jr. (www.prlog.org/11754388-livingstone-college-hires-consultant-to-implement-study-abroad-program-for-north-carolinas-hbcus.html), (http://countynews4you/2012/03/18/survivor-of-1994-rwandan-genocide-speaks-at-livingstone-college/) coordinator of the NC SAGE Partnership and I will own all related marketing, recruiting, fund raising and student support tasks.

And what if we don’t reach our financial goal?

Because of Indiegogo's flexible funding feature all funds, this campaign receives, will be used toward program implementation expenses. I apologize for not currently offering perks. This will change soon.

And what if we do and surpass it?

Even if funds raised exceed $26,980, they will roll into Phase 2 operations. Functions include: student application processing, building database, selecting cognitive science instruments and learning impact metrics; including pre-departure and administrative program implementation activities not covered by application fee. 


The Impact

Broad, it’s to have measurable impact; we will track post-event student performance. This program’s future development will be based on data analysis before scaling. Beneficiaries: recent college graduates, their families and communities; regional economies and all of America. When recent graduate unemployment rises and federal student-loan default grows, for six years in a row, we all loose.


Other Ways You Can Help

We honor all contributions, irrespective of size. But if you cannot contribute at this time, you can play an important role in this campaign by sending this link to your friends and anyone who feels that more of our students must be global-ready. Be a part of this higher education innovation to improve U.S. graduate marketplace success, because just going to college is not enough.

Thank you in advance; more later.

P.S. At the top of our page on the left is Livingstone College's: Jimmy McNeill,III a Biology major from Rocky Hill, SC who is targeting medical school. This photo was taken in Peru last summer.

story:
Who are we?

We are a group of Singaporean undergraduates, who lead Hall 10 (a university's residential hall) Overseas Community Involvement Programme, and are passionate about contributing to the global community. We have been working with HOPE Worldwide for the past 6 years in an effort to raise the level of education and help the needy children in Indonesia.

This year, we want to do more! We will be going to Indonesia from 3rd to 16th June 2013 to not only teach the kids basic English, but to refurbish their schools as well. We have noticed that not all the children have a full set of stationary and are looking at providing them with their own sets too. We are now trying to raise funds to better help the children that we will be visiting in the villages and English Training Centres (ETCs) of Hope.

Why?

We believe that everyone, no matter how young, has a part to play. 

How?

You may question, how can we help the children in just 2 weeks?

In the 2 weeks, we aim to inspire and help the children to learn English by showing them that it can be fun to learn. When they are able to grasp this language, their chances of employment greatly increase, and over time, this helps with the country's economic advancement. 

We will also help them refurbish their schools to cultivate a better, more conducive, learning environment. We will also be building recycling bins to inculcate a sense of environmental awareness. By instilling this attitude in the young, we hope that they will grow up to lead the country in a more socially responsible way.

Although 2 weeks is not long, this is ultimately a long-term project that that we will continue with for years to come. 

What do we need?

Your help! Every little bit counts. The money that we are campaigning for will go directly into funding programme materials and construction materials for our 2 weeks in Indonesia. The breakdown is as follows:

Construction materials: $500

Stationary for 500 children: $1000

Art and craft materials: $800

Recycle Bin materials: $400

English worksheets: $300

 

TOTAL: $3000

Through this platform, we are hoping to raise at least $1500 to give the children the opportunities they deserve. With every dollar you give, you help to make their lives a little better. Everyone deserves a chance to dream and grow. Only education can help the children to be so much more. 

 

What do you stand to gain?

We don't have much we can offer but if you donate more than $10, we will send you a handmade Thank You card from the children themselves!

(Please note that all donations are in USD as this site doesn't accept SGD.)

Help us in other ways too!

  • Share! By sharing this page, whether on social networks or by word of mouth, you can help us reach out to more people so that more funds can be raised to help the children.

  • We would love to hear from you if you think you can help us in other ways. Email us here: rachel.ocip@gmail.com

story:
My name is Coach Chris Glasgow. I have been coaching these special group of young men since they were seven and eight years old. They are now 12 and 13 years old. In the neighborhood that these young men come from their is a lot of gang violence and recruitment for gang members. I have been amazed that our team has mostly stayed together with the limited funding we have for our football program. Before my son wanted to play football I had no idea how to coach or any desire to be a Coach. Like any other parent I use to take my son and stand on the side watching them practice. One evening one of the Coaches asked me if I wanted to volunteer as a Coach, since I was always at practice. I saw this as an opportunity to spend time with my sons, each on a different team for the organization. 

At first I was just your basic helping out dad but after awhile I really started getting into  coaching the kids and realized it was my responsibility as a coach and father figure, to some of them, to  impact how these kids grew into young men. I am a firm believer that "it takes A Village to Raise a Child". I have watched these young men mature and gain confidence in themselves as well as learning how to work with others for a common goal. These young men had endured years of losing until they turned the corner about 5 years ago and began a winning tradition in our Bronx based community sports organization.

For the last 4 years our team has been invited to the National Youth Football Championships held in Florida. The same youth championship games that have been recently featured on ESPN. We would be the first team in our Organizations 10 years of existence to make the trip to Florida and represent our community in the Bronx. We have lost many of our players who played for our organization to the allure of street life. Even with our success we have not been able to translate the wins into large group of kids playing football and leaving the gang and street life alone. I believe with this kind of exposure on a National stage giving us a chance to tell our story, we can get many more children and their parents involved in our community based organizations. That would give our kids some of the tools needed to be a success in any arena whether it be in school, business or life in general.

With your contributions you would be fulfilling these 16 young men dreams as well as helping a community realize that through sports and community based organizations that children can develop the confidence and self assurance to rely on positive influences then the glamorization of gangs and street life. For these 16 young men the memory of going to the National Youth Football Championships in Florida would last a life time. Thank You for your help in Making Their Dream Come True........


What We Need & What You Get

We have a total of 16 young men that would make the trip to Florida for the National Youth Football Championship. Though our organization has been fundraising all year long much of the funds generated were to keep up with the organization expenses. This team would be the first team to go to Florida to represent our organization as well as our community. So far, the combined efforts of the parents/children selling candies and the selling of our tee shirts we have raised 55% of the monies needed to make our children and the organizations Dream Come True! 

Here is a Breakdown of Cost per Child for 7 days (December 9-15) :

Airfare (round-trip) per child - $197 + $32(taxes) = $229

Hotel Accommodations per Child (4 in a room)  - $175

Food allotment per child - $120 

Ground Transportation per child - $100

Total per child for 7 days - $624

Grand Total for 16 members of the Team - $9984

We have raised approx. $5300

If we fall short of our campaign goal all of the proceeds that have been raised will go towards the expenses for the trip. Any amount of money would help in reducing the young men expenses.


The Impact

By contributing to our cause you will not only make the dreams of 16 young men, our organization and the community we represent come true but you will help in the reshaping of the ideology within the community to not accept things as status quo involving the gang violence, obesity and lack of programs for our youth. We have launched similar projects before for the betterment of our community. So far, we have seen success in gaining the trust of our community and gaining the ear of our political representation. But we all know that you need funding to get any project really going and that is where we have hit a brick wall. Hopefully, through the success of this campaign we can begin to put some monies behind the ideas we have developed that would help the youth in our area develop into successful young men and women. Their is nothing better then seeing young men and women feel good about their accomplishments and a community that rallied around them. For that we want to THANK YOU.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We ask that you please tell others about our cause to send these Young Men to Florida.
  • Please  use the Indiegogo share tools on this site.

       THANK YOU FROM THE NORTH BRONX COWBOYS JR. MIDGET TEAM
story_txt:
My name is Coach Chris Glasgow. I have been coaching these special group of young men since they were seven and eight years old. They are now 12 and 13 years old. In the neighborhood that these young men come from their is a lot of gang violence and recruitment for gang members. I have been amazed that our team has mostly stayed together with the limited funding we have for our football program. Before my son wanted to play football I had no idea how to coach or any desire to be a Coach. Like any other parent I use to take my son and stand on the side watching them practice. One evening one of the Coaches asked me if I wanted to volunteer as a Coach, since I was always at practice. I saw this as an opportunity to spend time with my sons, each on a different team for the organization. 
At first I was just your basic helping out dad but after awhile I really started getting into  coaching the kids and realized it was my responsibility as a coach and father figure, to some of them, to  impact how these kids grew into young men. I am a firm believer that "it takes A Village to Raise a Child". I have watched these young men mature and gain confidence in themselves as well as learning how to work with others for a common goal. These young men had endured years of losing until they turned the corner about 5 years ago and began a winning tradition in our Bronx based community sports organization.
For the last 4 years our team has been invited to the National Youth Football Championships held in Florida. The same youth championship games that have been recently featured on ESPN. We would be the first team in our Organizations 10 years of existence to make the trip to Florida and represent our community in the Bronx. We have lost many of our players who played for our organization to the allure of street life. Even with our success we have not been able to translate the wins into large group of kids playing football and leaving the gang and street life alone. I believe with this kind of exposure on a National stage giving us a chance to tell our story, we can get many more children and their parents involved in our community based organizations. That would give our kids some of the tools needed to be a success in any arena whether it be in school, business or life in general.
With your contributions you would be fulfilling these 16 young men dreams as well as helping a community realize that through sports and community based organizations that children can develop the confidence and self assurance to rely on positive influences then the glamorization of gangs and street life. For these 16 young men the memory of going to the National Youth Football Championships in Florida would last a life time. Thank You for your help in Making Their Dream Come True........



What We Need & What You Get
We have a total of 16 young men that would make the trip to Florida for the National Youth Football Championship. Though our organization has been fundraising all year long much of the funds generated were to keep up with the organization expenses. This team would be the first team to go to Florida to represent our organization as well as our community. So far, the combined efforts of the parents/children selling candies and the selling of our tee shirts we have raised 55% of the monies needed to make our children and the organizations Dream Come True! 
Here is a Breakdown of Cost per Child for 7 days (December 9-15) :
Airfare (round-trip) per child - $197 + $32(taxes) = $229
Hotel Accommodations per Child (4 in a room)  - $175
Food allotment per child - $120 
Ground Transportation per child - $100
Total per child for 7 days - $624
Grand Total for 16 members of the Team - $9984
We have raised approx. $5300
If we fall short of our campaign goal all of the proceeds that have been raised will go towards the expenses for the trip. Any amount of money would help in reducing the young men expenses.



The Impact
By contributing to our cause you will not only make the dreams of 16 young men, our organization and the community we represent come true but you will help in the reshaping of the ideology within the community to not accept things as status quo involving the gang violence, obesity and lack of programs for our youth. We have launched similar projects before for the betterment of our community. So far, we have seen success in gaining the trust of our community and gaining the ear of our political representation. But we all know that you need funding to get any project really going and that is where we have hit a brick wall. Hopefully, through the success of this campaign we can begin to put some monies behind the ideas we have developed that would help the youth in our area develop into successful young men and women. Their is nothing better then seeing young men and women feel good about their accomplishments and a community that rallied around them. For that we want to THANK YOU.


Other Ways You Can Help

We ask that you please tell others about our cause to send these Young Men to Florida.
Please  use the Indiegogo share tools on this site.


       THANK YOU FROM THE NORTH BRONX COWBOYS JR. MIDGET TEAM

story:
Akamai means intelligence or common sense in Hawaiian.

Akamai Learning will have a nourishing home-base where students can strengthen their nature-based studies with modern technology. 

I am Felicia Cowden, the school director of Akamai Learning, which is essentially alternative middle school supporting families that identify as home schoolers. My longer-term background has been in business, engineering and public policy. My experience of running a group home-school program for four years, is that students learn the most vibrantly when they are engaged in applied science, math and social studies. They learn WHY and WHEN they need the skills that straight academic study generally only demonstrates the WHAT and HOW of a math or science application. Modern financial and civic literacy is entwined with nature-based and Hawaiian cultural learning from the mountain to the ocean.

Many students are physical learners and can become frustrated by being trapped in a desk with a necessary strong set of rules five days a week. Akamai Learning has evolved to placing an emphasis in nature, grounding the students in food production and directly managing the aspects of nature around them. We go on field trips to understand the relationship of the modern world, the natural world, the subjects we study and our responsibility for building a resilient future.

Akamai Learning has been a smaller program based out of my home, often learning traditional skills at Waipa which is a 1600-acre Hawaiian culturally-based learning center. This year, we are taking the leap from having an Akamai Backyard to having an Akamai Ahupua`a (watershed valley) by moving from my house to Waipa’s campus. This year we have 25 students who will be experiencing traditional, more vocational practices with Waipa’s staff in their farming and wilderness areas. This learning will be complimented with more core academics, modern technology and direct instruction in the new building. Fresh food from our growing area will be available for the students to graze on in our kitchenette. In order to service families of all economic ranges, we have a minimal tuition. We need help furnishing the new learning center.

What We Need & What You Get

The Waipa Community has been blessed with a beautiful new building funded by Kamehameha Schools. It now needs to be furnished and Akamai Learning is its first regular user. This will be a community classroom as well as our own.

We need about $2,500 to set the room up with communication technology. This includes the internet cable, a large, wall-mounted television/computer screen, an interfacing laptop computer, modems and routers. Another $2,500 is for the basic furnishings of large whiteboards for different walls in the room, tables, chairs, wall-mounted maps, locking storage cabinet for student work, cooking equipment for the kitchenette, yoga balls, some hand-crafted furnishings like big bean bag chairs, a recycled palette couch, and a whiteboard-surfaced table.

The rooms will be flexible, comfortable and have a number of multi-directional learning areas which can be almost swept aside to empty the room for a hula halau and other open space uses. The video screen will assist many users in making robust group presentations.

The $5000 amount represents a collective furnishing cost. If there is more money, we can invest in more quality equipment. If there is less money, we still have moved in the direction of having what we need.

This community building is available to other organizations through making reservations with Waipa Foundation. www.waipafoundation.org

Setting an example for culturally appropriate empowered learning

First and foremost, we want to make a difference for any student that is directly in our program to learn in a direction that inspires their passion and sense of purpose. Their education embraces much more than what they experience directly on campus and inclusively respects their family and life circumstances. We work to not only help them to build their dreams but also to identify them. There is a lot of freedom and self-direction in this program as students begin to recognize that all of their life is their school. 

Student-directed learning is the natural trend for education away from teacher-centered schools. It is more effective, affordable and relevant. Learning from experience in the real world that is tied to academics is retained. The educational standards set in the urban settings of Washington D.C. or even Honolulu have a serious disconnect to what matters to a child in a rural island environment. Ask any surfer how much they are learning when they are out in the water and are those lessons of value.

Akamai Learning hopes to demonstrate a template that can be adapted to anywhere. 

Please see our earlier film we made at www.akamaibackyard.com . We have a goal next year to create another film that shares our educational concepts to the larger world. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this request with folks you believe may be able to help us.

You may have a talent you would like to share with our students or program. You may also have some of the items we need. e-mail to akamaimom@gmail.com

Check out our building the dream page on our website www.akamailearning.org

story:
HELP MAKE A TEACHER'S WISH 

COME TRUE!!!!


What We Need

Our teachers, related services professionals and staff work miracles with students every day in Pleasantville.  They want to do more and do an even better job for the students but the budget only allows for so much.  The teachers have put together a Wish List of items that they could use to enhance the education and experience of the students in Pleasantville.  The teachers and related professionals from all three schools put items on this wish list.

The Impact

Your contributions will allow teachers, related services professionals and staff to give students the opportunity to experience the latest technology, software, games, equipment, books, sensory items, furniture, and other items that will enhance the educational experience for the students in Pleasantville.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please contribute but also make sure you share with family, friends, and professionals that care about your child and helping students with special needs in general.  Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share share share!!!!! Also, remember your contribution is tax-deductible!!!

story:
Cinemics is a unique online platform which teaches Computer Programming, Science and Math to kids using Digital Comics and Superheroes.

Keeping kids engaged and motivated can be a challenge, even for the best teachers. Comic books and Superheroes have the magic of captivating any kid's undivided attention. With Marvel and DC churning out blockbusters year after year, it is no surprise to know the impact they have on the young minds. Cinemics is an attempt to tap the potentials of comic books and superheroes and use them to make learning a fun filled experience.

Cinemics has a three point system:

Motivation: 

Each course will have a comic strip in it taking the member on a superhero adventure journey. The comic strip will stop at a suspense juncture and you can proceed further only if you watch a educational (Science, Math or Coding) tutorial video and successfully pass the assignment quiz. So, if you want to know what happens next in the comic book, you better pass the assignment!

Accountability: 

Superhero power points are assigned to member with completion of different sections of the course. Superhero board will display the weekly, monthly and yearly leader in the board. The more frequently you work towards the completion of your course, the more points you earn taking you to the top of the board. Compare your superhero power points with others, compete in the arena and become a leader of the superhero team!

Creativity:

With each important section of course completion you unlock the potential to build your own superhero. It begins with selecting the power of your superhero, selecting the costume, side kick and many more. Explore the creative part of your brain while learning to code.

We are a team of dedicated technologists and creative artists working towards making learning fun. We have worked towards designing our own superhero characters with complete storyboard and character design. Find below some of our exciting characters:

Name: RUDRA

Power:

 Concentrated Infrared Radiation from his eyes can burst things to ashes. He is the commander in chief and strategist of the team.

Name: AGNI

Power:

He is well trained in martial arts based on animal style. He can manifest 

himself through fire i.e. he can move from one place to another fast 

through fire (just like how forest fire spreads).



Name: VAYU

Power:

He can run as fast as the wind due to his ability to harness wave power.

Name: JAL

Power:

He can form and control ice. He can also create protective shell out of ice as needed. He can also cause freezing in specific, localized area.


We are also working hard towards preparing our fun course curriculum which will teach Web Designing for Kids using these Superheroes. Efforts are driven towards making the course dynamic and entertainment based along with filling it with detailed learning sessions to strengthen the basics of learning to code. The course curriculum will touch upon the following technologies which are in high demand in the current IT development:

 


In future the courses are only not limited to technologies but It will also have courses on Math and Science.

For us to bring Cinemics to life, we need your support!

Your generous funding will help us getting things started in order with our concept.

It will assist us with the cost of illustration for our comic book series. development and functional design of the pending features of the web application. 

More importantly you get the chance to be one of the first users of "CINEMICS". We will also use our funding to test our concept to make it better.  We are committed to continuous improvement so we are always giving people the best possible solutions.

10% of our every member registration will be donated towards charity causes dedicated for betterment of education for underprivileged.
