story:
Who I am..

My name is Pete Marchica, and I am the founding festival Director of the Rose Park Bluegrass Festival. For the last 10 years I've worked as a bartender here in Long Beach, CA, and loved doing it for mainly two reasons: 1) I seemed to be pretty good at it. 2) I loved that the main component of my job was meeting and working with new people. Although as much as I was attached to that line of work, and loved doing it, I wanted something more. I realized that as much as I enjoyed meeting new people and seeing smiles on their faces when I poured them a libation, I knew that the job had it's limits. I wanted to travel, I wanted to be creative, and I wanted to use the ideas that constantly ran through my head to help increase the level of happiness for people in this world. Basically, I had outgrown my job, and knew that the act of pouring somebody an alcoholic beverage was only a temporary fix, for improving the level of happiness of others around me. 

 

Here's what I want to do

This Campaign will directly fund the production of the 2nd Annual Rose Park Bluegrass Festival. The event is a collaberation with the Rose Park Neighborhood Association (RPNA), which is committed to maintaining and improving the quality of life for the residents of the Rose Park community. It's a free festival, directly in the middle of a densely populated area of Long Beach, CA. 

                                   
The festival itself is more than just bluegrass music, arts & crafts, delicious food, games, and prizes; it's a living entity that draws people out of their homes, and into the presence of their neighbors. It's a conversation starter. The Festival is a place where friendships begin, and relationships blossom under a common, shared experience. It's not about bluegrass music. It's not about good food. It's not about contests and prizes. The Rose Park Bluegrass Festival is about enjoying the company of your fellow neighbor, and being happy.
 

Through funding the production of this festival, your contribution will ultimately yield:

  • 5 solid hours of Free Bluegrass music
  • Free arts, crafts and activities for children
  • A measurable level of gross domestic happiness for the residents of Long Beach, California.
  • The use and full potential of a public park
  • The attention to a neighborhood that might normaly have been overlooked, because of it's challenged past
  • And much, much more...
            
 

What We Need..

In order for an event of this magnitude to continue to be free, we need your help to pay for the much needed infrastructure and the highly skilled talent of those who help organize it. Here are some of the things that your contribution will specifically fund:

  • The Bluegrass Bands (you gotta pay the musicians)
  • The staging, soundboard and electrical power generator
  • Street Closures (so people can roam freely, without having to worry about cars)
  • The Free Bike Valet (So folks can park their bikes - worry free)
  • Porta Pottys (so folks have somewhere to use the restroom)
  • The countless Permits required (as much as these are needed for the safety of attendees, they are very, very expensive)
  • The organizing staff (web designers, graphic designers, adminstrative assistants, interns, etc.)
  • Advertising (both online & in-print)
  • Office supplies: paper clips, file folders, ink cartidges, etc. (not everything can be done by email)
  • Food and refreshments for the volunteers on the day of the event
  • And tons more....
                    
 
In addition to the banjo/fiddle contest that takes place on stage, the pie-eating contest, and the make-your-own instrument workshop for kids, this festival pays homage to what is now a very special tradition. Before the final band performs, 4 outstanding residents of the Rose Park community will be recognized during the "Distinguished Roses" designation. All recipients are nominated because of their undeniable committment to the neighborhood, and will receive a long stem rose, a framed award certificate, and a commemorative brick with their name engraved, to be placed on the walkway in Rose Park. The bricks will be purchased from the Rose Park Neighborhood Association (RPNA) a recognized non-profit 501(c)3.
 
        
 
 
In the unfortunate event we do not meet our financial goal for this campaign, "The Show Must Go On..." as they say. There may be certain aspects of the festival that we might not be able to deliver on, but the festival will happen either way, even if it means me sittin' in the park on August 19th with a banjo, all by myself. 

 

The Impact of what you're contributing to..

This festival will directly contribute to the happiness of the residents of Long Beach as well as garner membership for the Rose Park Neighborhood Association (RPNA). I urge everyone to watch the video provided with this campaign, and for every smiling face that you see, for every laughing child and every new friendship made, know that it was all possible because of you. 

         

 Other Ways You Can Help

If for any reason you are unable to contribute financially to this campaign, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Please get the word out about this campaign: Tell your friends, your friend's friends, tell your friend's friends' friends, tell everyone you know!!!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools on social networking sites you belong to.
  • We'd love if you can Volunteer on the day of the event. Just visit: www.roseparkbluegrass.com/donate/ for more information.
  • Most of all.... please just come to this event!

Advertising (both online & in-print)

Food and refreshments for the volunteers on the day of the event
And tons more....

                    

 
In addition to the banjo/fiddle contest that takes place on stage, the pie-eating contest, and the make-your-own instrument workshop for kids, this festival pays homage to what is now a very special tradition. Before the final band performs, 4 outstanding residents of the Rose Park community will be recognized during the "Distinguished Roses" designation. All recipients are nominated because of their undeniable committment to the neighborhood, and will receive a long stem rose, a framed award certificate, and a commemorative brick with their name engraved, to be placed on the walkway in Rose Park. The bricks will be purchased from the Rose Park Neighborhood Association (RPNA) a recognized non-profit 501(c)3.
 
        
 
 
In the unfortunate event we do not meet our financial goal for this campaign, "The Show Must Go On..." as they say. There may be certain aspects of the festival that we might not be able to deliver on, but the festival will happen either way, even if it means me sittin' in the park on August 19th with a banjo, all by myself. 


 
The Impact of what you're contributing to..
This festival will directly contribute to the happiness of the residents of Long Beach as well as garner membership for the Rose Park Neighborhood Association (RPNA). I urge everyone to watch the video provided with this campaign, and for every smiling face that you see, for every laughing child and every new friendship made, know that it was all possible because of you. 
         
 Other Ways You Can Help


If for any reason you are unable to contribute financially to this campaign, here are some other ways you can help:

Please get the word out about this campaign: Tell your friends, your friend's friends, tell your friend's friends' friends, tell everyone you know!!!
Please use the Indiegogo share tools on social networking sites you belong to.
We'd love if you can Volunteer on the day of the event. Just visit: www.roseparkbluegrass.com/donate/ for more information.
Most of all.... please just come to this event!

story:
Short Summary

Chace Topperwien was diagnosed with AML (Acute Myeloid Leukaemia), a rare and agressive form of leukemia, on the 14th of March 2011, just 3 days before his second birthday.

He has been battling the disease for 12 months, undergoing months of brutal chemotherapy and a stem cell transplant in July last year. However, just days after Christmas, the Topperwien's learnt Chace's leukemia had returned and were told there was nothing more doctors could do (and that Chace likely had only weeks to live).

His parents, Keri and Ryan, desperately searched the internet for anything that could help their only son, and just when Chace was at his worst they discovered a promosing new drug trial in Britain. The drug blocks the activity of a group of proteins called aurora kinases that control cell growth, inhibiting the growth of cancer cells.

After spending his third birthday in Auckland's Starship Hospital (tha makes it 2/3) Chace and his parents have flown halfway around the world, away from the support of their whanau, to join the hugely costly experimental drug trial which is the last desperate hope to prolong his life long enough for a second transplant to be attempted.

What We Need

The trial is going to cost the Topperwien's up to $423,000. They have flown to the UK with just $69,000 (raised for just such an opportunity in 2011), less than a quarter of the amount required.

The family are facing a bill of at least £13,470 (approx $27,000 NZD) for just the first 10 days of the trial (this covers the cost of the hospital bed, 2 Echo tests, 2 chest x-rays, an ECG, plasma, 1 unit of platelets every 2-3 days, haematology, chemistry, cross match x 2, BMA x 2, 2 histograms, HA7). And that does not include Keri and Ryan's own living expenses or unexpected hiccups like the recently discovered kink in his port, which needs to be replaced at additional time and expense.

All of the funds raised go straight to the Topperwien's and will be used to cover the expenses of his trial and their living costs in the UK.

The Impact

Treatment on this trial is Chace's only hope of survival. Chace is adorable, adventurous and life without him in it is unimaginable. Keri and Ryan are beautiful, intellegent, and amazingly positive people who have touched the lives of many, both before and after this saga began. This is just the kind of whanau we want to support and foster in Aotearoa.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just aren't able to contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Think about joining the Bone Marrow Donor Registry http://www.bonemarrow.org.nz/join-now/. They are in particular need of donors of Maori or Pacific Island descent. It's as simple as donating a unit of blood and asking to be added on the Bone Marrow Donor Registry. That's all it takes.

story:
Our Story

The Right to Learn is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing the disadvantaged children of Nagarote, Nicaragua with a free, Montessori education. The Right to Learn accomplishes this mission primarily through its funding of School of Louise’s Dreams, where over 200 pre-elementary and elementary students are provided with everything they need to effectively receive an education.

Over seventeen years ago, our school began as a simple dream of one woman. During Louise Brunberg’s first visit to the town of Nagarote, she witnessed the poverty suffered by many of the children. As a retired teacher, she was especially saddened when she learned that many of the children could not attend the public schools because they were unable to afford basic necessities like school supplies, shoes, or even breakfast. It was then that Louise decided that she would dedicate the rest of her life to ensuring that those same children would be able to attend school, regardless of their circumstances. Today, The Right to Learn works to continue our founder’s dream.

Inspired by the ideals of the organization, I began working as a Development Intern for The Right to Learn in April of 2011. Using Social Media, I have been helping to bolster The Right to Learn's internet identity, gaining the organization as much positive awareness as possible. At the end of the summer, I will journey to Nagarote with Louise Brunberg herself, to begin a Teaching Internship. After many months of working on the business side of this non-profit, it will be incredibly rewarding to experience The Right to Learn's work first hand.

The Impact

Providing free education for an entire student body is no mean feat, so we are not always able to provide the students of The School of Louise's Dreams with everything they deserve. We hope to increase the presence of the Montessori method in our classrooms, in order to enhance the students' overall educational experience. After all, these pupils, with their well rounded academic careers, will soon be the leaders of their communities and country.

What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign goal is to enhance the implementation of the Montessori Method in our classrooms. When I visit Nagarote, I hope to bring interactive, advanced materials for the students, such as craft supplies, books, building materials, games, and outdoor play equipment.

To demonstrate our appreciation of generous donors, givers of $25.00 or more will receive a colorful photo collage of the students of The School of Louse's Dreams.


How Else You Can Help

One of the many terrific outcomes of this campaign will be increased publicity for The Right to Learn. The more people know about our mission, the more sustainable we become. Visit our website, or follow us on Facebook and Twitter!

http://www.therightolearn.org

http://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Right-to-Lear...

http://twitter.com/#!/TheRighttoLearn

story:
Young Navajo Filmmaker, Camille Manybeads Tso, who made her award winning film “In the Footsteps of Yellow Woman” when she was 13 years old, has been accepted into the top film high school in the country, Idyllwild Arts Academy. She received a large scholarship for the majority of her tuition and her family and community has already helped her to raise the remaining $6,000.00 in tuition.
Now, she has the means in which to learn and hone her craft, she just needs the tools.

We are working to help her buy a new MacBook Pro computer, software including Final Cut Pro and Adobe CS5, an external hard drive, and a printer.

Unique Incentives include an ‘I sent Camille to film school’ button, a personalized video thank you, a credit in Camille’s next movie, a copy of Camille’s award winning film, “In the Footsteps of Yellow Woman”, and an hour of free filmmaking / Final Cut Pro consulting with Camille (on Skype or in person, location permitting).

Check out the trailer to In the Footsteps of Yellow Woman in the Gallery

Please spread the word by sharing on all of your social networking sites and email.
Thank You!

story:
FALLEN NOT FORGOTTEN

Fallen Not Forgotten, Inc. was founded in October of 2012.  Since that time we have been able to successfully raise enough funds to establish three small college scholarships:  Our first was given to Macae, the son of USMC Sergeant Joseph Wrightsman that was killed in action (KIA) in Afghanistan on 18 July 2010. Our second was established for the three-year-old daughter of Sergeant Enrique Mondragon (USA) who was KIA on Christmas Eve, 24 December 2012 while conducting dismounted patrols in Baraki Barak, Afghanistan.  And our third one, established for the now 7-year-old daughter of 1st Lieutenant Jason Mann who died while serving in Afghanistan 17 July 2008 as part of the 24th MEU.  At this time, Fallen Not Forgotten asks for your continued support in celebration of our service members and their families who have paid the ultimate sacrifice on our behalf. 

A CALL TO ARMS

In July 2008, after laying a friend to rest that was killed in action while conducting combat operations in support of Operation IRAQ FREEDOM, I was discussing with a mutual friend about various programs available to the families of service members that were wounded or killed in action (WIA/KIA).  It was during this conversation that his mother innocently offered the statement “Well I always thought you all took care of your own!”  For the past few years the loss of that friend and unfortunately additional ones since then has fueled Fallen Not Forgotten to take action and attempt to do just that!

The U.S. Department of Defense reports as of May 2, 2014 there were 3, 481 KIA and 31,941 WIA in support of Operation IRAQI FREEDOM, 38 KIA and 297 WIA in support of Operation NEW DAWN and 1,805 KIA and 19,551 WIA in support of Operation ENDURING FREEDOM. 

COLLEGE FOR CALI

As some of you may recall, this past winter during our “mini Goal” Fallen Not Forgotten was able to raise funds for several iPad mini’s!  It was at that time that we were introduced to the Baldwin Family and a gold star child – Cali.  Cali is the daughter of Chief Baldwin who was a Sea Bee in the US Navy.  In speaking with her mother, I was informed that Cali would be graduating from high school this year with the intent on attending college next year!

Given a computer, some time to think while baking in the 100 degree Djiboutian hot sun, and a wifi connection…FNF felt compelled to see what we could do to assist in paying for Cali’s first year of college (though we always welcome more).  In doing a quick review of Mississippi Gulf Coast Community College Summary of Per Semester Expenses for full time students, I quickly realized just how attainable this goal is.

MISSISSIPPI GULF COAST COMMUNITY COLLEGE BASIC CHARGES (per semester)

Tuition (12-21 credit hours)*

$1,150.00

Registration Fee

$50.00

Book Service (per book)**

$30.00

Technology Fee
($3 per semester hour not to exceed $36)

$36.00

*Note: Students enrolled in more than 21 credit hours in a semester will be charged a per-credit hour fee of $115 per credit hour for all credit hours above.

**Note: Some courses require students to purchase their textbooks and/or other instructional materials rather than participate in the Book Service program. Students may contact the campus bookstore prior to registration to determine required purchases.

HOW CAN YOU HELP

Fallen Not Forgotten asks that you contribute any amount that you can spare to make this goal happen – it is really that simple. So forgo your specialty drink at the local coffee shop, eat leftovers opposed to going out to lunch today at your favorite restaurant, empty out that change jar that you’ve been stowing away, share some of your tax returns, or any other creative way you can come up with to make this happen!

Nothing fancy…no gimmicks…just you and Fallen Not Forgotten working together to remind our gold star families that we have not forgotten them and appreciate everything they have given up.

If you can’t afford a financial contribution at this time there are other ways you can help.  For example simply getting the word out via social media such as Facebook, Twitter, Google Plus, smoke signals, courier pigeons, or any other way that people may connect with us. 

FEES:

To provide complete transparency the following administration fees are applied:

Indiegogo (our host): Charges 9% on all contributions unless we meet our goal. (4% is refunded if Fallen Not Forgotten reaches or exceeds our goal at the end of 120 days.)

PAYPAL:  ON TOP of the fees applied by Indiegogo, PAYPAL charge an additional 3-5%  per contribution.  

Fallen Not Forgotten, Inc:  We do not charge anything and all funds received from this site, minus the fees mentioned above, are donated to the gold star families of Fallen Not Forgotten, Inc.

 SPECIAL NOTE FROM THE PRESIDENT OF FALLEN NOT FORGOTTEN, INC:

I am an active duty service member that has not forgotten the sacrifices paid by our service members overseas as well as their families at home.  I, like many of you, have experienced the loss of many friends throughout the past twelve years and know in my heart that these are not “someone else’s kids” …these are “our” sons and daughters and they deserve our help to ensure they are well taken care of. 

Thank you for visiting the site and taking the time to consider contributing!

story:
Who am I.

My name is Gabrielle Morbitzer. I am a recent college graduate from The Ohio State University where I graduated cum laude with a dual degree in International Studies and Spanish. After finishing college, I knew for certain that I had certain passions, but I had no idea how I would combine these seemingly different concepts together to create a cohesive vision and course of action for my future. I delayed applying for graduate school and dedicated myself to finding a way to connect the dots. 

I have known for some time now, that yoga teacher training ambiguously fit somewhere into the life I had a lways dreamed for myself. For many, many months after practice, I would sit in a forward fold with my eyes closed and think, someday I will do my training. Usually, this is when thoughts would creep into my consciousness. Thoughts of inadequacy, mostly. I would think about how I need a few more difficult poses before considering this seriously. I would think about how I needed to be able to do standing splits without wanting to scream my head off. I would think about how I need to get to a point where trying to kick up into a handstand wasn't the worst feeling in the world. 

However, I recently spent a weekend in New York where I had the opportunity to practice with some truly powerful souls who wiped all of my own insecurities off the board, and turned them into laughter mostly. The thought of studying and journeying within this community has been such a motivating force for me to fund my teacher training in any way possible. I also knew that New York was where I absolutely had to be in order to experience my training. I wanted to be exposed to all that New York has to offer, to be a sponge to the diversity of knowledge that certainly exists within this community.

The studio that caused this fundamental shift of my perspective is called Strala Yoga and they offer a teacher training program in March and April. My goal is to be there. 

At Strala Yoga, I experienced an authentic expression of self, perhaps more powerful than anything that I have ever shared with the universe. And so I believe within my core that I cannot ignore what my inner spirit is gravitating toward.

What I am asking for.

I decided on crowd sourcing for a few reasons. Primarily, I believe so deeply in the power of community. All of my most powerful experiences in life have come from community building and I feel as though this initiative will only fortify that. I have had a number of people ask me how they can help me reach my goals, and so making the opportunity available will be mutually beneficial. I can imagine that it would be unique and special for my friends and family to understand that they have been directly responsible in my success in following through with what my heart is set on. 

I currently have a goal to raise 1,500 dollars and I have given myself one month to meet this goal. This amount will cover the deposit and will give me time to continue to build savings in order to pay the remainder by March. I set this goal because I believe that it is very much attainable. Any contribution will help me get where I need to be. 

Yoga is my future. But it is not mine alone. By contributing to my cause, you will also be contributing to exposing people all over the world to this practice. I truly feel as though my practice will go global in the future and I want you to be a part of making that happen. I cannot say for sure how this will manifest exactly, but think empowerment, strength, awareness and appreciation of self. Think of how these emotions can cross borders, can overcome language barriers, should be accessible to all human beings. And think of how it would feel to be a contributor to this. 

What else you can do.

If you cannot financially contribute, or want to know how you can help me otherwise, consider how far support can go. Sharing my campaign with others. And even if they are not able to contribute either, perhaps they will understand the essence of why I am so passionate about this cause. That holds a whole lot of power for me in itself. 

Additionally, you can ask me to lead a practice or meditation for you or for a group. I have some experience of doing this and would actually appreciate more practice and growth as I work on developing my own personal practice. I would be happy to do this and I will never ask for anything in return. This will help me more than you know.

Please consider how a small community of us can make a large scale difference. For me, it is not necessarily about a bottom line dollar amount and I believe that is what will ultimately make this project successful. However, the reality of the matter is that I do need financial help to get there. And I'm not afraid of that.

What I am asking for.
I decided on crowd sourcing for a few reasons. Primarily, I believe so deeply in the power of community. All of my most powerful experiences in life have come from community building and I feel as though this initiative will only fortify that. I have had a number of people ask me how they can help me reach my goals, and so making the opportunity available will be mutually beneficial. I can imagine that it would be unique and special for my friends and family to understand that they have been directly responsible in my success in following through with what my heart is set on. 
I currently have a goal to raise 1,500 dollars and I have given myself one month to meet this goal. This amount will cover the deposit and will give me time to continue to build savings in order to pay the remainder by March. I set this goal because I believe that it is very much attainable. Any contribution will help me get where I need to be. 
Yoga is my future. But it is not mine alone. By contributing to my cause, you will also be contributing to exposing people all over the world to this practice. I truly feel as though my practice will go global in the future and I want you to be a part of making that happen. I cannot say for sure how this will manifest exactly, but think empowerment, strength, awareness and appreciation of self. Think of how these emotions can cross borders, can overcome language barriers, should be accessible to all human beings. And think of how it would feel to be a contributor to this. 

What else you can do.

If you cannot financially contribute, or want to know how you can help me otherwise, consider how far support can go. Sharing my campaign with others. And even if they are not able to contribute either, perhaps they will understand the essence of why I am so passionate about this cause. That holds a whole lot of power for me in itself. 
Additionally, you can ask me to lead a practice or meditation for you or for a group. I have some experience of doing this and would actually appreciate more practice and growth as I work on developing my own personal practice. I would be happy to do this and I will never ask for anything in return. This will help me more than you know.
Please consider how a small community of us can make a large scale difference. For me, it is not necessarily about a bottom line dollar amount and I believe that is what will ultimately make this project successful. However, the reality of the matter is that I do need financial help to get there. And I'm not afraid of that.

story:
Today, I come to you asking for your help.  Higher education in West Virginia is having financial difficulty.  Running a department that now has 530 majors, 23 full-time faculty and dwindling budgets is not an easy task and that's why I need you.  
 
What I am asking is that those who are able to do so consider donating to the  funding of our two new labs in the new applied engineering building, which I currently have no funding to equip.  An immediate goal of mine is to raise enough money to place computers in the labs ($40,000).  Secondary and lofty is to raise another $40,000 for additional equipment in the new building, which is set to open in approximately 13 months.  
 
You now have an opportunity to give back and help us continue to grow and stay current.  Any financial gift will help, no matter how small.

story:
Let The Children Play Zimbabwe is hosting an International camp and beyond that provides platform for the young musicians each school holiday and long weekends teaching and giving them an opportunity to put what they have learnt into practice.

OVERVIEW:
Overnight camp, based , Zimbabwe, for young musicians. The goal of the camp is for young musicians to find a meaningful connection with the world around them through music. Students form bands and select the genre of music they want to play. Each band chooses a social issue they want to address through music. Each band composes, shares ideas across cultures . Students will be exposed to musical styles from around the world, as well as issues faced by communities around the world, through local and international instructors. The camp will include a service learning project, as well as a final performance.

DURATION: 11 days

DATES:
August 11-22 2014 (overnight)

FOR WHOM: young musicians, girls and boys (maximum of 40 students)

STAFFING:

  • ­  music instructors will be professional performers from the USA, Zimbabwe, Italy and Zambia

  • ­  camp counselors would be

    CONTACT:

    Sekai, Music that matters assistant Director +1 215 909 2102

    Elisha Herema, Let the children play (Zimbabwe)
    +263 77 364 6229 waltdubes2@yahoo.co.uk

    Nsamu Moonga, Gray Nkhoma Ensemble (Zambia)
    +260 96 533 2931 mwendandende@gmail.com

    Massimo Covini, Zimbo-Ita (Italy)
    +39 320 603 1468 maxcovini@hotmail.it

    Sandra Rizkallah, Plugge-In (USA)
    +1 781 956 4281 sandra@pluggedinband.org

Camp PROGRAMMING (August 11-22 2014, Zimbabwe)

­ Theatre games sessions to “workshop” and physically engage with social issues - National night “Each country to share a brief history in song”

  • ­  Form bands and learn one “cover” song that has a social focus

  • ­  At least 3 guest performers for evening performance and Q&A session

  • ­  Weekend songwriting workshop

  • ­  Rehearse original songs, plus individual music lessons with instructors

  • ­  Informal evening jams/movie sessions, and other educational/recreational activities

  • ­  Short morning sessions on social issues, as well as group sessions about challenges students may be facing with the songwriting process

  • ­  Rehearse original songs, plus individual music lessons with instructors

  • ­  Music video feedback sessions

  • ­  End camp with a final performance of cover and original songs, as well as performance by instructors. Final performance will also include music video screening.

    A typical day at camp will include a number of fun activities, which will help students enjoy becoming better musicians! As a group, we will explore issues of social justice and learn how musicians around the world are using their music for just causes. In our bands, we will write music together, learn music together and play music together. There will be group classes where we learn about music from around the world, play new instruments, explore technology used to create music, make instruments and so much more.

    All of this sound like fun? There is more! In the afternoon we will relax and spend time outdoors. We will have beautiful grounds and sport facilities that we can use to do activities aside from music. We will explore, listen to others perform, eat ice cream and probably jam some more!

story:
UPDATE... We have paid the $100 for the Camp Inventions for Leilani and Jr.  We are still working on Kaylee's Trip to D.C.  The total cost of the trip is $1700.00.  I applied for a scholarship and was granted $249.00, making total owed $1451.00.  If you would still like to help you can send via check to Kaylee's Acct. Message me for address, or you can send via Paypal.. mnichols007@hotmail.com.  

Kaylee has been selected to join classmates on a trip to Washington D.C. for Pre AP students at Travis Middle School. The cost for the whole trip is 1800.00.  She needs a downpayment just to get registered for this trip. Deadline for this is May 15, 2014 

Leilani and Jr. are both G.T. (Gifted and Talented) Students at Brandenburg Elementary and have the opportunity to attend Camp Invention this summer, sign ups are first come first serve and time is running out. This is a great opportunity to be with other G.T. students and invent awesome things this summer. 

Leilani is making and shipping out Rainbow Loom bracelets for anyone that donates $10 or more.

story:
Read More about the  "Designing Your Future" Citizen Schools apprenticeship on the Hindsite Metrics Blog.

Colgate Alums, Medvis Jackson ('11) and Ben Gulla ('11) have teamed up with Citizen Schools to teach a 10 week Web Design apprenticeship to 7th graders at the Isaac Newton School for Math and Sciences in East Harlem, NY.

Throughout this course, as students learned about the importance of purpose, design, and usability, Mr. Jackson and Mr. Gulla wanted a away two reward one or two individuals who went over and beyond the requirements of the course.

Such rewards would show the payoff of diligence and self-application to both award winners and their classmates. More importantly, these laptops will hopefully propel to young citizens of New York City from economically challenged and marginalized neighborhoods into the world of technology and design.

Join Us as we seek to embolden and equip the brightest and best in our community.

Rewards

  • $500 donations- Thank you letter from reward recipient ,and a picture of award recipients with laptops and of class. And lunch with Mr. Jackson and Mr. Gulla.
  • $100 donations- Thank you letter from reward recipient ,and a picture of award recipient with laptop and of class.
  • $75 donations- Photo of class and laptop award recipient.
  • $50 donations- Social Media Shoutout and a Personal Thank You card from Medvis Jackson and Ben Gulla.
  • $25 donations- Social Media Shout Out and Personal Thank You email.
  • $10 donations- Social Media Shout Out

story:
Hi! My name is Dana.

I study in art school. I really enjoy painting. I study various drafting methods and history of pictorial art. I realize that nowadays in the century of innovations it`s important to keep with the times. I`d love to pick up working on the drawing tablet with LCD screen. This technology provides new opportunities for people! But on the other hand I understand that traditional ways of drawing – brush, pencil etc. are impossible to replace, as real artists started from such small things! However, I don`t want lag behind technical progress. I mean if I ever start working in this area, I`ll have to work with the computer equipment and even graphic tablets.

Please help me to achieve my dream and buy this device!

Thank you in anticipation for your help!

story:
Who We Are

We are a not-for-profit organization dedicated to creating socially sustainable communities and thriving workplaces in Colorado. We partner directly with employers to help provide job-retention services to their employees.  We help employees get to work, stay at work, and be productive at work.

We work collaboratively with government agencies, training centers, and other nonprofit organizations to provide the individualized services each employee needs to overcome work-life issues.

We take a holistic approach towards helping people overcome the barriers that obstruct their work-life balance. Common areas of assistance include: child care assistance, financial health, food assistance, health care, housing, transportation, job coaching, and stress management.

What We Need & What You Get

WorkLife Partnership began in 2009, originally serving only Denver County. Demand for our services has spread to Weld and Larimer Counties where we have operated for over a year, but lack a home office.

WorkLife has an opportunity to make our home in Loveland's Life Center. The Life Center houses 10 other nonprofits all geared toward helping families in Larimer County become self-sufficient. WorkLife's working presence there would fill a gap for Colorado's working poor that the city would not otherwise have. The cost for the build-out is $8,000.00.

The Impact

There are only 4 models like WorkLife Partnership in the country. WorkLife's office space would help serve 1000s of working families in Northern Colorado, and will help leverage the myriad of resources from the other nonprofits housed at Life Center. WorkLife will work collaboratively with the other agencies to help bring more support into the Northern Colorado community. The space will also be used to conduct job training, financial literacy classes, and skills training.   The space will stand for years to come for future nonprofits to utilize.

" Whatever good things we build end up building us." - Jim Rohn

Other Ways You Can Help

Word of Mouth: If you know of someone who might be interested in our cause we would be obliged for you to pass along our information.

Social Media: If you have an affinity with the work we are doing, make sure to let your friends and family know with a social media post. We're on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google+, Youtube, and Pinterest.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is BJ Heinley and I'm a designer, artist, and father of two kids here in Austin. I'm passionate about storytelling and creating amazing experiences for kids disguised as author/illustrator Bear James. I'm currently working on two children's books and organizing a kid's festival... and, uh.. making spin-art machines!

Why Oversized Spin art machines? 

We have several festivals coming up, and this project will allow kids to quickly create a gigantic, immersive, and meaningful piece of art to hang in their home. The finished work is up to 3 feet! I can tell you firsthand the satisfaction kids have making and completing a project of this size in minutes, and hanging it in their home.  

What is Spin Art? 

Glad you asked. Check out this Wikipedia Article. Also, here's a cool video (go to the 2 minute mark) and an example of some Spin-Art by artist Damien Hirst that sold at auction for roughly 6 million dollars!

This project is cool because there's also an Art + Tech + Science angle. Having a tactile activity is proven to be an effective learning technique. During the making of the art we'll discuss the science of centrifugal force, the Big Bang theory, and the mechanics of the spinning engine. Trying to predict how the color will mix is also an interesting topic.

These machines will also help contribute to fundraising at elementary and middle schools so help me get this thing funded!

What We Need & What You Get

What we need:
  • $500 is the minimum for two oversized spin-art structures, including box materials, the electrical work, the engines, clips, etc. 
  • $300 for an initial round of paint, paper, canvases, and containers. 
  • Any extra goes towards drying racks, wheel castors, step stools and other small items like clips, tape, etc that will further enhance the experience. We'll always be able to buy more paint, canvas, and paper. Someone just mentioned using a black light and fluorescent paint. Fun! 
What you get:
  • Photos of the process and results will be on the Bear James website 
  • If for some reason we don't reach our goal, the funds will offset the costs of one of the boxes that's currently being built.  

The Impact

Art is facing endless challenges in our public schools.There's a need to create opportunities that help strengthen our children's artistic, creative, and critical thinking skills that spans all subjects and disciplines.

Risks & Challenges

Making the spin-art machines is simple in theory but requires woodworking and electrical skills, testing, refining, and craftsmanship to actually make it go well. We're building two machines to have a backup so there's no immediate disappointment at an event with breakage, and to share with other festivals. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out. The best way you can help! Share with your friends, your school group, church, or whomever you think might help us achieve our goal. *

Follow along at Bear James and we'll keep you informed of other projects like this one!

*IndieGoGo's got some amazing tools that will help get the word out!

story:
Hello Everyone!

My name is Megan, and I am in my third year of college at Johnson State in Vermont. I major in Creative Writing and minor in Gender Studies. My hopes is to use the tools I learn at school to go forth in the world and help people. I plan to write novels and books as well as political articles to bring awareness topics within Gender Studies. 

Johnson is amazing, it is where I found my best friends. I have learned an incredible amount in my fields of studies, and I have managed to make friends that are more like family to me. I've never felt like I fit in before, but here at Johnson, I have a group where I feel like I belong.

I am an excellent student. The first semester of freshman year I got on the Dean's List, and I was only a few grade point shy of making Dean's List the second semester. Last year I was on President's List both semesters. I have a cumulative grade point average of 3.815. Last year I was awarded the Roger Roth/Mark Canavan award which is awarded to the best Creative Writer at Johnson. I have had teachers try to recruit me to change majors or apply for internships because of how well I did in their classes, and a teacher even asked me to write them a letter of recommendation.

I enjoy school, and I love Johnson. I have learned so much and met so many wonderful people. However, this semester my financial aid got messed up, and I have absolutely no way to pay the money.

I go to school full time throughout the week in addition to working a minimum wage job on the weekends. Because of how little my job pays and how little hours I am able to work, I cannot pay for my own schooling very easily. My parents cannot help with my student bills because they live paycheck-to-paycheck and struggle to pay even pay our bills; therefore, every little donation helps.

If I do not raise this money I will not be able to return to college this year, or at all. I will have to start paying for my student loans and bills, which will require full time work and then some. Raising this money not only helps me stay at school this year, but it allows me to continue coming to school until I graduate. 

Remaining at college allows me to better myself with knowledge about my studies, and the world; stay with my closest friends who have become like family to me; and get opportunities to work in my field of studies through internships and other opportunities. Anyone willing to help donate would be helping me continue to do the things I love and eventually help other people, and I would be extremely grateful.

story:
Dear Christians, and friends of Christians,

My ministry requires me to be driving on the road at the rate of more than 25,000 miles a year, or more than 2,000 miles a month. That means I am behind the wheel an average of 70 miles a day. My 2006 Volkswagen Rabbit has reached the 205,000 mile mark on the odometer. With the help of God it has served me well for all of those many miles. It has been a great blessing due to the Parishes, and Faithful I have been priviliged to serve. (See the photo gallery link above to view some of the churches I have visited with the Rabbit) But the transmission is slipping more and more often, and engine repairs are apparently in the near future. It is only a matter of time before something major gives out and I find myself on the side of the road. The law of averages dictates, because of where I am needed most of the time (the great Midwest, or wherever Metropolitan Demetrius needs me), when I do breakdown I will be hundreds of miles from home, and from our trusted mechanic Mike of Astoria, NY.

The prudent thing to do at this point is to donate the Rabbit to a needy family, and get another Volkswagen (VW has proven itself to me) and start the journey of another (God willing ) 200,000+ miles traveling that ribbon of highway, and serving our Church anew.

Our Holy Metropolis does not have the funds for this particular need, so we are relying on the generosity of the Faithful. Anyone who donates, in any amount, no matter how small, will get a receipt from the Church that can be used as a tax deduction.

May God bless all of you!

+Bishop Christodoulos

story:
Hello Everyone,

I am trying to raise $3,000 to finish my Bachelor of Accountancy Degree. I was accepted into the Masters degree program at school because of my outstanding work ethic, but the only thing stopping me is the money it will take to finish paying for my degree. I have finished my bachelors degree, but cannot get my transcripts to move on until I can finish paying the school. 

I have applied for scholarships and loans, but this has proven fruitless, as so many students can attest to. As you might imagine, being able to attain my Bachelor's degree was a hurdle financially, and having the transcripts being held is preventing me from moving forward. The Master's program is so close, and being told I can go no further until I pay off my balance is more than heartbreaking and very frustrating.

I've worked very hard and have a great GPA, but my Stafford Loans ran out because in January 2014 I fell very ill and was hospitalized for a short time. I sustained a serious concussion from a fainting spell that has caused extremely debilitating "rebound headaches" that are more akin to migraines, all while taking care of my 17 month-old daughter (at the time) and my 6 year-old son. As a result I was forced to miss a few classes, and even though I have medical documentation on file at school, their financial aid department is unable to help me. Hence the remaining balance. Grievances with the school have been unsuccessful. 

My husband, who has done all he can to help with the kids while working a full-time job and I downsized our lifestyle significantly, selling many of our belongings and moving out of the suburbs into a very small town in a house half the size of our other home. Rob is working extra hours, not to mention extra hard, to help raise funds, but it's just not enough. That's why we sincerely need your help.

I am not one to ask for help - in fact, we have given to charities and GoFundMe campaigns for friends when we had very little money to give, we've sponsored entire families every Christmas to make sure they have a Christmas (this year is no different than any other), and when we did so we believed that there would be no chance that we would ever find ourselves in a similar situation. We were wrong.

As it turned out, we have found ourselves in the exact same position. There are months when it's difficult to pay for basic utilities, let alone save money to finish school so I can improve the quality of my family's life.

Even if it's just a few dollars, anything you can spare would help a family of genuinely good people who have just found themselves going through a serious financial rough patch.

Your next question may be, "How will $3,000 get you through your Master's Degree? Well, the government has approved Stafford Loans sufficient enough to cover my entire Master's program as long as I can pay off my Bachelor's program, which is why it's so important that I finish this goal. As you can imagine, it's very frustrating to be so close, but seemingly so far away, unless the kindness of strangers will help get me through. Will you please help my family and I? Any amount, no matter how small will help us greatly, and every penny you send will be used for only one thing: my tuition.

story:
Short Summary

  • We are The Youngs of Lawrence, KS.  We might be your friends, your family or the ones who sling your drinks, bread, and tacos. We might be just a familiar face, or some folks you don't know at all. We're pretty ok, and we need your help. 
  • We've never tried to live beyond our means but with the state of the economical climate we have limited resources to keep us afloat. We're trying to take a creative approach to asking you lovely people with some financial assistance. Because let's face it, it sucks to ask for a hand out.  We love you and thank you in advance if you should decide to contribute. 
  • With your help, we will get out of this financial hole, and you will and can receive some rad stuff, showcasing what we're good at doing or what we're good at accumulating.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need anywhere in the neighborhood of $1500. We're happy to receive any amount, because anything is better than nothing. 
  • With your contribution you can receive a special item from us that will be our Thank You, for helping us in this trying time. We have groovy stuff, a clever child, and many talents to share with you. 
  • If the entire goal of $1500 is not reached, then the money earned from this campaign will still go towards paying off the man, to pack some more dirt on the hole.
The Impact
  • With your help, we can continue to survive, thrive, and serve the fine people of this community. More importantly, get our child to and from school, and keep us from living under the bridge leading to North Lawrence. 
  • We like making stuff, cooking stuff, being weirdos, and we'd like to share that with all of you. We have a lot of love and energy to give, and some of it can be yours for a very modest price, and/or free because we love you, just ask!
  • Our vehicle just recently got repossessed and we are behind on most other bills including, mortgage and electricity.
Risks & Challenges
  • This has been a hard road to cross, but with the factors in play at this moment, we have little choice but to ask our community of friends and family for help.
  • With your help, we can overcome the financial burden that outweighs us at this point.  From there, we can hopefully, get our feet back on the ground and continue fighting the good fight, and get out of the red. 
Other Ways You Can Help
  • Every dollar helps.
  • We'd take hugs.
  • If you cannot donate, no big deal! We hope you enjoy our campaign.  We put a great deal of "Fort Youngitude" into this thing and we hope you at least got a chuckle out of our misfortune.  
  • If you'd like to share, that would help a whole heap!

story:
iCoach wants to become the first and only One-Stop Career Site for Coaches providing solid jobs, certifications and access to all current training tools to keep teaching kids honesty, integrity and sportsmanship.

 




iCoachConnect 

We started with a very ambitious goal; Bring the job search for coaches out of the stone age and into the electronic age. We thought word of mouth and a 3x5 card posted on a high school bulletin board or on a district website was not a sufficient way to hire a schools next coach and role model to our student athletes. We thought the job responsibilities deserved more, we thought you deserved more so we started iCoachConnect.com. Our next goal is to provide coaches with the most current training tools, videos, live clinics, interviews, certification opportunities, and personal branding webinars. All the tools needed to win at your present position, add credentials to your resume and keep being a positive role model. 

We Win as a Team.

Our research tells us there are approximately 6-7 million coaches in the United States and more entering the profession every year. There are more coaches than jobs so it's becoming harder and harder to land a coaching job. We have made the process much easier for you by creating iCoachConnect. We also believe proving the latest training techniques is the next important service we want to provide you to help you win now or help you secure a new coaching position. 

Here are some of the benefits and services we want to add to iCoachConnect,

· Provide On-line live interactive clinics: so you don’t have to pay hundreds of $$ to advance your personal off season training 

· Teach You Personal Branding: To really get those head coaching jobs schools now want to see your Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn accounts. They want to see if you have a personal blog with original ideas and evidence of having an online following. It’s really easy and we have lined up some of the best in the business to show you how.

· Coaching Certification training that leads to more opportunities and higher pay

However, to become the Premiere Site for Jobs and Coaches Training Tools well, we can't do it alone. We need your help. We need to win as a team. We need to raise the necessary funds to hire programmers, more researchers, a social media professional and an advertising sales person. We don't believe coaches should have to pay for essential training to coach our kids.

We are connected with lots of coaches on LinkedIn and Twitter and I have read all your profiles and I tell you honestly, We're just like you. I want to say thanks to all the coaches and schools who have tweeted and emailed me thanking us for finding them jobs and helping them hire coaches.

I’m particularly proud of the email I received from Lisa Johnson from Monticello High School, MN who thanked us for helping them find a head swimming coach. If they didn’t find one soon, the sport would be dropped.

Your emails inspire us to do more. And we can with your help. Our mission has always been to create a nationwide“Fraternity of Coaches” where coaches not only find jobs but also training videos, interviews, clinics, and certifications at no charge. 

The role you play in our student-athletes lives are just to important.

We Want Coaches to Focus on Coaching and Teaching Kid’s Right from Wrong. Not pay for the training tools to be better coaches.

Your donations add more services and benefits for all the coaches who make a huge difference daily with our student-athletes. 



iCoachConnect provides coaches a straightforward and  FREE Online Site where
talented coaches can apply for open coaching positions simply by filling out a
profile and schools can post their jobs and immediately get profiles from some
of the best coaches in the nation.

Now coaches will know about all the great new jobs posted and be notified immediately by text or email and schools can receive those profiles immediately so they can choose from hundreds of coaches and never worry about getting enough applicants to satisfy board regulations.

The best part is, parents can be reassured that the teams your kids play on is
being coached by a qualified and positive role models that teach good
sportsmanship, fair play, honesty and integrity.




To continue providing this valuable FREE service the iCoachConnect website needs to be updated. The money raised by this crowdfunding campaign will be used to:

You see, helping coaches find jobs is just the beginning. Our ultimate goal is to create a portal where coaches will not only find new jobs but have access to all the tools and training necessary to be the best coach, role model, educator and mentor they can be. The winners are our student athletes.

We appreciate your generous contributions to support the message of fair play,
honesty and integrity that coaches teach our kids who are our most precious
resource and who become the next leaders of our nation.

Please contribute generously and receive some of the terrific rewards we are offering. Your contributions will insure that iCoachConnect.com will remain a FREE service for every coach and every school. If you can’t contribute we
understand but you can still participate by spreading the word about all the
good work we are doing.

If you’re one of the lucky few coaches, parents who are 100% satisfied with your
coaching jobs or with the coach who’s coaching your kid’s team congratulations!
– Then do your fellow coaches and parents a favor and support us.

Remember there are still thousands and thousands of student athletes who sure could use a new coach, teacher and positive role model.



iCoachConnect was launched in 2007 with a simple goal – help every coach find the right jobs at the right school to become a positive role model for our student athletes and we are succeeding.

By word of mouth only and no advertising budget we have more than 40,000 coaches, schools, ADs, and associations in our database and members in over 50 countries; iCoachConnect has posted over 45,000 jobs in the past 5 years. 




I'm passionate about the role coaches play in the lives of our student athletes. Thousands of kids might have taken a different road in their lives if not for the guidance and support provided by their coach.

I was one of them.

I was coming off a great junior year and the expectations for a great senior
season was sky high. I even had thoughts of playing basketball in college but
everything came to a screeching halt. I had lost touch with my dad for the
first time in my life, as he practically fell off the face of the earth.
Instead of talking to him on the phone every night to see how my practice went
and how life is going, I hadn’t heard from him in weeks.

I was about to quit playing until my coach, Coach Heinz sat me down before
practice one day. He could sense something was wrong. I explained to him how my
dad’s abrupt disappearance had been occupying my thoughts all season, which
made basketball nothing more than an afterthought.

“I’m sorry to hear about your dad,” Coach explained, who didn’t quite know what to
say yet. “Maybe you could use basketball as an outlet to forget about what’s
going on in your life.”

It was sound advice, however, he continued on with a suggestion that would alter
how I lived the rest of my life. “It would make your dad proud as hell if you
kept playing basketball and turned this season around,” Coach Heinz said.
“Maybe you keep your dad in mind for the rest of the year and play for him.”

Coach Heinz was there for me. He was more than my coach. He was my mentor, my role model. He taught me lessons that go far beyond the basketball court. He taught me that what goes on off the court is just as important as what goes on, on the court. Coach Heinz did not just teach the skills, technique and strategy within
the narrow confines of basketball. No, instead he looked for opportunities
where the more important life lessons can be taught such as mastering hardship,
handling and rebounding from failures and setbacks, trusting your teammates,
sacrificing individual needs for the benefit of the team, emotionally dealing
with winning and losing, good sportsmanship, fair play, honesty, and integrity.

What coach taught me stayed with me and it got me thinking of how many other kids were influenced by their coaches, and how many more kids could benefit from a good coach.

Coach Heinz was my motivation behind iCoachConnect.






  • Add Thousands More Jobs  Every Month!  

First thing we will do is add staff to search and post thousands more jobs. In addition we want to create a job harvester that will search the Internet daily to add thousands and thousands of new jobs domestically and globally to increase coaches opportunities to find a great new job. 

  • Increase Functionality

Right Now Coaches can Create a Resume, Search for Jobs and Apply. We  want to give coaches the opportunity to upload their own resumes and cover letters. We want to add text capabilities to so coaches can be notified immediately when a new job is posted that matches their qualifications. We want to customize the website so it can be viewed in mobile applications.

We want to add a message board where coaches/ADs/Schools/Clubs can post information about clinics, games, messages, buy, sell, and trade equipment

  • More Brand Awareness

We want to increase awareness and membership through a dedicated social media campaign to increase membership and attract corporate sports sponsors so coaches will have a generous supply of open coaching positions and remain a free site for every coach and every school. Create an iCoachConnect YouTube channel where coaches can upload :30 videos to increase exposure and awareness.

  • Training Tools

We plan to broadcast live training webinars, podcasts, interviews with high profile coaches, players and sports executives. Partner with Universities to provide Advanced Coaching Certifications that lead to salary pay increases.


GENEROUS DONATION REWARDS

story:
Short Summary

Gathered in our customary circle on the floor of our rehearsal space, I asked the cast of 11-14 year old actors a simple question: “Is Macbeth appropriate for you?”  I had allotted ten minutes of discussion in that night’s rehearsal schedule— I would review the email that I had sent their parents the night before (in which I relayed the plot of the gruesome tragedy and assured parents that we would handle the material sensitively and with respect for children’s unique needs), and we would quickly, as a group, discuss the merits and challenges of working through such controversial material.  That discussion lasted nearly two hours. 

As I expected, students agreed—unanimously and immediately—that they could tackle Macbeth.  Hands flew in the air as our conversation jumped from their familiarity with political violence to experiences with familial pressure and bullies at school.  The young actors observed that, like Macbeth as king, bullies are often insecure about their position on the social ladder.  They brought up the frequency of addiction and mental illness among celebrities as we talked about the pressures and perils of fame. “Macbeth can never be happy with what he has,” one student observed, “and so his ambition becomes like an addiction.”  We delved into gender roles, comparing the pressure boys often feel to be less sensitive and emotional as they enter adolescence to Lady Macbeth’s demand that Macbeth prove his masculinity by killing King Duncan.  When I brought our conversation to a close, the students groaned. After nearly two hours of focused, energetic, and entirely student-driven text analysis, these 11-14 year olds still had more to say.  As I left our circle to prepare for snack time, I listened to the students’ giddy debriefings.  “That was amazing!” I heard, “I feel so grown up talking like that about Shakespeare!”   

---

The Oberlin Children's Shakespeare Project (OCSP) is a not for profit children's theater based in Oberlin, Ohio.  At OCSP we are committed to the idea that everyone-- regardless of age or education level-- can understand Shakespeare. Whether through after school rehearsals, summer acting intensives, or one-time workshops, we aim to foster a safe and creative space for kids to discover what Shakespeare's words mean to them. 

Following two extremely successful productions (As You Like It in the summer and Macbeth in the fall), OCSP has announced plans for an ambitious spring show as well as another summer intensive. We are here to stay-- with three shows a year, a full-time director, and a dedicated company of young actors! 

What We Need 

 OCSP is now a fully functioning nonprofit enterprise-- and we need the funds to match all that we hope to do!  In order to expand our programming while providing a salary for a full-time staff member and stipends for part-time staff, and maintaining our current production schedule in 2015, we will need a minimum of $20,000.  Hopefully, most of that money will come through grants, but we also need as much donor support as we can get!
Here's a quick list of what we need and why we need it:
  • iPads: From line memorization to lighting design to interactive Shakespeare games, there is a whole world of theater and education apps out there, and we want to access it!  iPads are at least $300, and we need at least 3 of them for ideal engagement (and to avoid fights!).
  • Swords: Because what is better than teaching 12 year olds how to sword fight?? Quality (i.e., safe and durable) swords start at $200 each.
  • Salary: Starting this summer, this is going to become my full time job. I will not take a full salary right away, but I would like to start taking a stipend as soon as possible.
  • Stipends for summer staff: OCSP staff are compensated for their work during the school year through Oberlin College credit, but that option is not available during our 3 week summer intensive.  While we do not expect to pay staff extravagant salaries working for OCSP, we do think it is only right to cover some of the living expenses of a summer in Oberlin.


The Impact: Why OCSP Matters

Oberlin is a small town 40 minutes outside of Cleveland.  In the Oberlin City School District, 54% of students are enrolled in the free and reduced lunch program, and 20% of students live below the national poverty line.  OCSP charges only $25 per semester, with full scholarships available to anyone who asks for one.  Of the twelve students in our production of Macbeth, seven were unable to pay the $25.  For the vast majority of my students, OCSP was their first experience acting in a play.  In the seven weeks that we rehearsed and performed Macbeth, I watched these twelve children conquer stage fright and Elizabethan grammar, as they grew into thoughtful, confident, and immensely kind young actors. 

If you believe in theater as an exercise in empathy and you believe in the power of the arts to transform young lives, please do what you can to help keep OCSP financially accessible to all who find us.  


Can't Give Financially? Spread the Word!

  • Share our online fundraiser on social media! Send it out to your mailing lists! Email your grandma! 
  • Know any 11-14 year olds in Lorain County? Send them our way! You can sign up for our spring 2015 production of The Tempest on our website: www.oberlinchildrensshakespeare.org

  • Contact us to see how you can help-- we always need more volunteers!

story:
For 39 years Revolution Books-Honolulu has been an oasis for all who find the current state of the world intolerable and who yearn for a better future.

In order to continue to keep its doors open in Honolulu we need to raise big money to pay down debts, meet increasing costs of overhead, and expand our stock of progressive books that speak to current events and trends as well revolutionary literature that puts forward a vision of the world as it COULD be.

story:
Youth Development Program (YDP) is an independent volunteer-based youth center, which brings positive impacts to Cambodian society by creating charity events and sharing information regarding to scholarship and job opportunities on our official Facebook page. We are currently holding one project called “My Book, My Future!”, which we have to build 4m x 4m square meters library which costs $2,500  for O Chrey’s students living in O Chrey village, Barang Tlak commune, Phnom Prek district, Battambang province. Our objective toward this project is to give them their own library and enhance their reading skills as it is important for them in the future, and so do society as a whole.

We do this campaign in order to raise more funds for our project since we lack of financial resource to pursue our mission. This campaign is really precious to us, YDP, to reach our mission and vision and to help those poor children who desperately need new library and books. Without your help, our YDP team may not be able to provide a complete library for those students, and we may not do any changes to our society as a whole. Studying is the right path to get rid of illiteracy, and it is worth to those who want to grab this opportunities; therefore, if we do not help them – who? And if we do not start from now – when? Your contribution and donation is really meaningful to us to give hope to those rural students.

To say the truth, we solely need $1,000 more to build a suitable library for O Chrey’s students in Battambang province, Cambodia. At the very first time, YDP had much sympathy to those children after visiting them and known their ambitious to learn, yet they do not have enough material and study areas. Therefore, we conducted Shine of Hope charity concert last year on the purpose of giving hope to them to learn. Admittedly, we got $1,500 fromour charity concertwe organized; unfortunately, it is not enough to help those children. Hence, I want you to help us to with your kind donation and contribution to our project because without your help we are hard to reach this mission. However, if we cannot reach this entire goal or we cannot get fund from you, we still do not give it up; we determine to pursue this project for a while and try our best to seek for more funds in any means.

This project is really extremely crucial and valuable to us, YDP, O Chrey’s students, the Cambodian society and the world as a whole. Without our help, those children surely do not have opportunities to learn or even how to read and write; this makes them blind of knowledge – knowing nothing and becoming poorer and poorer. Cambodia, which is a developing country, will lose many potential generations to build up society in the future. More importantly, the art of helping, sharing and giving hope to each other will make this world become shrinking world that people can turn to each other. Hence, if you help us by funding, we will use them for good way – building the library for those rural children and and providing them various kinds of books.

Here is the link to our video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r3aWmqhHMnk

story:
VERRB: The Summary

VERRB is a call to action. It is a mobile platform designed to inspire its users to abandon their comfort zones, take more risks, and engage their worlds in unusual and envigorating ways. Simultaneously, it provides a platform to showcase the movers, shakers, and trailblazers in the community that create those unusual opportunities for the users. 

VERRB serves two audiences: (1) the individual: you!, and (2) the "community builders": the entrepreneurs, artists, visionaries, and organizations who engage those individuals by creating unique experiences for them. VERRB brings the unconventional to your fingertips, from hot air balloon rides and fencing, to pottery classes and jazz on the rooftop. VERRB seeks to motivate and celebrate the trailblazer in each of us!

  • Our founders have a background in Public Policy, Cultural Diplomacy, Engineering, and Business, and desire to find creative, sustainable solutions to address social ills and foster a more vibrant community.
  • VERRB is about taking action; living richly; growing daily; facing fears . . . and having fun in the process. Life should be BOLD, not BORING!


What We Need & What You Get

  • VERRB requires approximately $60,000 for the development phase of the mobile technology: approximately 6 months. 
    $9,750/Month: 1 Android Developer; 1 iOS Developer; 15-20hour/week Backend Developer; Shared Resources: UI/UX Engineer/Designer & QA Engineers
    $250/Month: R&D, Marketing, Creative Development, Partnership Building
  • As a founding contributor, you will have early access to the mobile application, free lifetime access to all subscription options and upgrades, and your name will be listed on the corresponding website as our founding contributors! 
  • If you would like to be an investor, please send us an email, and we would be happy to discuss those options with you!
  • All funds will continue to go towards research and development, whether the amount of contributions exceeds --or falls short-- of the initial projected goal. Once the development phase is fully funded, excess funds will be invested into Phase 2 of VERRB: marketing and growth. 

The Impact

VERRB is first and foremost a social enterprise, with the primary goal of affecting postive social change using sustainable, innovative, and mobile technology. VERRB is a mission-driven business dedicated to (a) individual empowerment, (b) community development, and (c) sustainable social change. VERRB is not only about offering a service; it is about changing a mindset.

Your contribution, whether it be $1.00 or $1,000, will have a tremendous impact on this vision. We want to create a more vibrant, more engaged, more invigorated world. We see too many young adults -- at the prime of their lives -- stuck in their comfort zones, and falling into empty patterns of un-enriching activities. And for those of you who love to explore the uncharted, there are simply not enough economic, efficient, or streamline tools out there. 

Risks & Challenges

We believe in transparency. So we want to provide some insight into the risks and obstacles we may face on the way to achieving this goal.

  • Challenges: The biggest challenge will be differentiating VERRB from "event apps" like EventBrite, Meetup, Google's FieldTrip, and other tourist and event services. While VERRB may include events in its offerings, that is not its defining feature. It is about a broader range of experiences -- that fall far outside the limited bounds of typical tourist activities and attractions -- and cultivating personal growth in the process.
  • What Qualifies Our Team? Our team is not unused to hurdles, challenges, and overcoming them. Our tech team alone, Appable, has successfully launched 13 mobile applications over the past 2.5 years. We believe in innovation, creativity, resilience, and vision. The motivations behind VERRB are far deeper than commercial gain; we strive to create something that enriches the lives of our users and encourages social progress. 
  • Jumping the Hurdles: We plan on reframing the concept to show the social benefits to both individual users, the community, and the small businesses and visionaries that VERRB is designed to serve. We also anticipate maximizing user experience through innovative design . . . and including YOU, and your feedback, in the process! 

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you can't contribute financially, don't worry!! You are still valuable to us, and we would love for you to be a part of this vision! 

"How do I do that?" you ask? Well, in the nature of VERRB, it's all about ACTION! :)

  • SPREAD the word! Make some noise about the campaign; tell your friends and family, 
  • PROVIDE feedback! We also encourage your feedback so we can learn and grow! We love having a diverse membership -- including artists, designers, technologists, and entrepreneurs -- to encourage the cross-fertilization of ideas. We want to create a platform for showcasing and sharing ideas with expert communities and the public, to be developed in collaboration with YOU, its members.
  • STAY involved! Feel free to contact us with your thoughts. Ultimately, this vision is for YOU. Tell us how we can serve you more. Discuss it among your fellow trailblazing community; and tell us how we can make this better!
  • SHARE with others! Indiegogo has some amazing share tools! You are welcome to use any of the options you see fit.


. . . . Thank You for Your Time! Please Keep In Touch!
