story:
Short Summary

Greetings Friends!

Nassolo, Nina and Took became dear friends to me when I lived and worked in Uganda as a Peace Corps Volunteer from September 2006 through November 2008. In 2009 I learned that their mother, Mama Nina, was sick with AIDS. She was no longer able to keep her daughters in school due to her illness and insufficient income. I am reaching out to you to ask for a contribution of any size toward the education of Nassolo and Nina.


What We Need & What You Get

The goal of this fundraising campaign is to raise $2,700 to pay for the last year of high school for Nina (the campaign video says two years, however one year has been paid for since making the video) and to contribute towards Nassolo’s second to last year of university. Nassolo is committed to working part-time to help pay for her education. If we are able to raise a total of $5,500, the extra funds will be used to pay for Nassolo’s last year of university and contribute towards Nina’s first year of university. Thanks to the generous contributions of my friends and family, Took graduated from high school last year with teaching credentials, Nina completed her second year of high school, and Nassolo started University. Your contributions to this campaign will help these motivated young women complete their educations.

All donations made to this campaign are tax-deductible through my partnership with the non-profit With God's Little Ones. Additionally, in appreciation for your contribution to Nassolo and Nina’s educations, I am pleased to offer you a gift with a touch of East African flavor. People who contribute at all levels will receive twice-yearly updates from Nassolo and Nina about how they are doing in school.

  • Contributions of $10 or more: an electronic thank you card featuring pictures from Uganda
  • Contributions of $20 or more: a physical postcard featuring photos from Uganda
  • Contributions of $50 or more: a postcard and a bag of fair-trade, organic coffee made with coffee beans from East Africa
  • Contributions of $100 or more: a post card, bag of coffee and a DVD copy of the fundraising film, including bonus photos of Uganda
  • Contributions of $500 or more: a personal thank you email from Nassolo and Nina, a post card, bag of coffee and a DVD copy of the fundraising film, including bonus photos of Uganda
  • Contributions of $1,000 or more: Five days free stay at the KACCAD Volunteer Center in Bulenga, Uganda (travel costs not included), a personal thank you email from Nassolo and Nina, a post card, bag of coffee and a DVD copy of the fundraising film, including bonus photos of Uganda


The Impact

By contributing to this campaign you make an investment not just in these young ladies lives but also in their family and community. Your contribution will ripple out as it empowers these young women to find meaningful work that pays a living wage, allows them to support their mother’s health care and living costs and reinvest their earnings back into their community. 

According to the World Health Organization, in sub-Saharan Africa fewer than one in five girls make it to secondary school.  Girls who are able to go to secondary school are more likely to earn a higher income and invest in their community and family. An extra year of secondary school adds 15-25% to a woman’s eventual income.  The World Food Program found that women who earn an income invest approximately 90% of their earnings back into their community through their purchases. Education strengthens women’s ability to meet the basic needs of thier families while boosting thier health, sense of self-worth and independence.

In Uganda public education is not an option past primary school. The limited primary public schools don’t have room for all the students, and they still ask families to pay a fee for attendance, uniforms and supplies, which is prohibitive to many families. Public primary school teachers are frequently not paid or underpaid and are frequently themselves undereducated. By secondary school there are no public education options.

The HIV/AIDS epidemic has heavily impacted many families, leaving parents unable to work and children orphaned. Other families don’t have the benefit of education themselves so their work options are mostly limited to subsistence farming, which does not provide them with income sufficient to send their children to school.

Your investment in the education of Nassolo and Nina will help these young ladies access competitive jobs that pay a living wage and support the long-term well-being of their families.


Risks & Challenges

Ugandan students take rigorous qualifying exams to pass from one grade level to the next. Some students don't pass these exams and are held back a year. There is a potential risk that Nassolo or Nina won't pass her exams and will be held back a year. Thankfully, Nassolo and Nina have done well in their studies to date. They have passed all of their exams with good marks. Their dedication to their studies will help them avoid being held back in school. 

Another potential risk is illness or family emergencies. It is common that students in Uganda are not able to complete school without interruption due to personal illness or family emergencies. However, Nassolo and Nina are part of a strong community that supports their family's well-being. In times when Mama Nina has been sick her extended family and friends have done what they can to take care of her. The same goes for her daughters. Nassolo and Nina have the best support possible from their community to stay in school when hardships arrive.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can help this campaign by getting the word out:

  • Share the campaign with your friends, family and coworkers through email, word-of-mouth and social media
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign with your community

You can also check out the Kyosiga Community Christian Association for Development (KACCAD) webpage for information about other projects to get involved with and more sponsorship opportunities. Check out KACCAD, my former host organization, at: http://www.volunteerkaccad.org/

Thank you for your life changing support.

With great appreciation,

Amanda Milholland
story_txt:
Short Summary 

Greetings Friends!
Nassolo, Nina and Took became dear friends to me when I
lived and worked in Uganda as a Peace Corps Volunteer from September 2006
through November 2008. In 2009 I learned that their mother, Mama Nina, was
sick with AIDS. She was no longer able to keep her daughters in school due to
her illness and insufficient income. I am reaching out to you to ask for a
contribution of any size toward the education of Nassolo and Nina. 

  What We Need & What You Get The goal of this
fundraising campaign is to raise $2,700 to pay for the last year of high school
for Nina (the campaign video says two years, however one year has been paid for since making the video) and to contribute towards Nassolo’s second to last year of university.
Nassolo is committed to working part-time to help pay for her education. If we
are able to raise a total of $5,500, the extra funds will be used to pay for
Nassolo’s last year of university and contribute towards Nina’s first year of
university. Thanks to the generous contributions of my friends and family, Took
graduated from high school last year with teaching credentials, Nina completed
her second year of high school, and Nassolo started University. Your
contributions to this campaign will help these motivated young women complete
their educations. 

All donations made to this campaign are tax-deductible through my partnership with the non-profit With God's Little Ones. Additionally, in appreciation for your contribution to Nassolo and Nina’s educations, I am
pleased to offer you a gift with a touch of East African flavor. People who
contribute at all levels will receive twice-yearly updates from Nassolo and
Nina about how they are doing in school.

Contributions of $10 or more: an electronic thank you card
featuring pictures from Uganda
Contributions of $20 or more: a physical postcard featuring
photos from Uganda
Contributions of $50 or more: a postcard and a bag of fair-trade,
organic coffee made with coffee beans from East Africa
Contributions of $100 or more: a post card, bag of coffee and
a DVD copy of the fundraising film, including bonus photos of Uganda
Contributions of $500 or more: a personal thank you email
from Nassolo and Nina, a post card, bag of coffee and a DVD copy of the
fundraising film, including bonus photos of Uganda
Contributions of $1,000 or more: Five days free stay at the KACCAD Volunteer Center in Bulenga, Uganda (travel costs not included), a personal thank you email
from Nassolo and Nina, a post card, bag of coffee and a DVD copy of the
fundraising film, including bonus photos of Uganda


  
The Impact 
By
contributing to this campaign you make an investment not just in these young
ladies lives but also in their family and community. Your contribution will
ripple out as it empowers these young women to find meaningful work that pays
a living wage, allows them to support their mother’s health care and living
costs and reinvest their earnings back into their community.  
According to the World Health Organization, in sub-Saharan
Africa fewer than one in five girls make it to secondary school.  Girls who are able to go to secondary
school are more likely to earn a higher income and invest in their community
and family. An extra year of secondary school adds 15-25% to a woman’s
eventual income.  The World Food
Program found that women who earn an income invest approximately 90% of their
earnings back into their community through their purchases. Education
strengthens women’s ability to meet the basic needs of thier families while
boosting thier health, sense of self-worth and independence.
In Uganda public education is not an option past primary
school. The limited primary public schools don’t have room for all the
students, and they still ask families to pay a fee for attendance, uniforms and
supplies, which is prohibitive to many families. Public primary school teachers
are frequently not paid or underpaid and are frequently themselves
undereducated. By secondary school there are no public education options.
The HIV/AIDS epidemic has heavily impacted many families,
leaving parents unable to work and children orphaned. Other families don’t have
the benefit of education themselves so their work options are mostly limited to
subsistence farming, which does not provide them with income sufficient to send
their children to school.
Your investment in the education of Nassolo and Nina will
help these young ladies access competitive jobs that pay a living wage and
support the long-term well-being of their families. 

  Risks & Challenges  Ugandan students take rigorous qualifying exams to pass from one grade level to the next. Some students don't pass these exams and are held back a year. There is a potential risk that Nassolo or Nina won't pass her exams and will be held back a year. Thankfully, Nassolo and Nina have done well in their studies to date. 
They have passed all of their exams with good marks. Their dedication to
 their studies will help them avoid being held back in school. 
Another potential risk is illness or family emergencies. It is common that students in Uganda are not able to complete school without interruption due to personal illness or family emergencies. However, Nassolo and Nina are part of a strong community that supports their family's well-being. In times when Mama Nina has been sick her extended family and friends have done what they can to take care of her. The same goes for her daughters. Nassolo and Nina have the best support possible from their community to stay in school when hardships arrive. 
  
Other Ways You Can Help You can help this campaign by getting the word out:  Share the campaign with your friends, family and coworkers through email, word-of-mouth and social media 
 Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign with your community
   You can also check out the Kyosiga Community Christian Association for Development (KACCAD) webpage for information about other projects to get involved with and more sponsorship opportunities. Check out KACCAD, my former host organization, at: http://www.volunteerkaccad.org/Thank you for your life changing support.
With great appreciation,
Amanda Milholland

story:
Nepal's monsoon season is quickly approaching and thousands of Nepalis are still without shelter. For every $100 we can provide a Nepali family with the materials needed to construct a durable home.

We are an independent group of 4 friends working closesly with both local Nepalis and other aid workers alike.

Our goal is to construct at least 10 homes for 10 families in the worst affected areas in the Kathmandu valley. As independent volunteers, we can ensure that 100% of the money raised goes to achieving our goal.

We are aiming for at least 10 homes but with each additional $100 we can provide another family with a safe place to lay their heads.

Thank you and Namaste!

For any questions feel free to email Kristin at - kristinherp@gmail.com

story:
We are COM408, a class studying "Media, Art and Social Activism" at The American Univeristy of Rome.  Our professor is Kristen Palana - artist, animator, filmmaker and social activist - and as a part of our coursework, we had to each propose a fundraising project; we voted which one to carry out, and this project was overwhelmingly supported by the class.  Prof. Palana has taught us the most amazing things this semester, and we hope, with your help, to use it all to help make this world a better place...starting with Yasini Biggo!

Yasini “Yacn” Biggo of Tanzania is currently studying law at The University of Dar Es Salaam. In his fourth semester at the university, a forward and innovative thinker, Yacn is studying in hopes of becoming a successful lawyer who can help the woman and children of Tanzania, and of his village who are isolated in society. His time at the university has been funded by generous crowdfunding that has allowed him to continue his education without taking loans from his already impoverished village.

Yacn’s original goal was to provide for his family. He is the only son of five children and feels responsible for providing for his mother and four sisters. His parents rely on unreliable small business ventures, and Yacn wanted to give them a comfortable life. It was after he left his village in Tanzania, when he realized that he could also help his community. It started with his family, but now he aspires to help the women and children of Tanzania who are neglected. He hopes to help those who are denied their rights of owning property, inheritance, work and live in liberty but instead live in extreme poverty.

Our mission is to help fund his education. With the drive and ambition he has shown thus far, he will achieve amazing things in his community. The first step for Yacn is to finish his degree, so he can then turn his focus towards helping others. Every year has been a struggle to fund his education and other expenses. We hope to provide enough that the financial burden is lifted so he can better focus on his studies. Tuition, fees, books, and a laptop—we hope to cover as much as we can. We would hate to see Yacn’s potential wasted because of the costly price of an invaluable education. 

We believe in his ability to effect and promote progress within his community. If it were not for the donations received through Aura’s House and other generous individuals, he would not have completed the first four semesters. He has come so far, and with your help we can assure he finishes what we all started together. With your donations we can help a great mind finish the first step in making a difference in the world. 

What we need and what you get:

  • We aim to raise a total of $1,500 to fund the following elements of Yacn’s education: tuition, fees, books, and a laptop.   The first three will cover Yacn's 5th semester of law school, and the last will help him with his studies - what student today can survive without a computer?!
  • In return for your contribution, you will have the most amazing feeling of having helped not just Yacn, but also every one of the people he intends to assist in his future efforts as a lawyer.  (Ahhh, feel that lovely karma!)  And if that weren't enough, Yacn will send out personal thank you notes via email!  In addition, depending on your donation, further perks include a raffle, recipes for Yacn's favorite food and paintings by AUR Fine Arts students - check out our perks section for how to get these very special gifts.  
  • If we don't make our entire goal, all funds raised will still be wired to Yacn's university for his tuition.  We'll post the receipts here once we get them.

Your contribution will have tremendous impact!

  • For one, Yacn is working all the harder at University, because he knows he's got so many people rooting for his success.  Just the fact that we're all trying has given him all the more renewed energy and determination to succeed as a lawyer. 
  • And Yacn's going to use everything he learns to help others in the future, people who really need a hand in Tanzania, people who otherwise would have no voice - women and children.  Your investment in this fine young man will have impact for years and years to come.  
  • We've already had one very successful campaign for Yacn (thank you, everyone who's back from that campaign!) via Aura's House, an online grassroots project who is joining us in this effort now as well.  (Please do check out AH - it has just celebrated its 10th year of helping children and our amazing Prof. Kristen Palana is its founder!)
  • Yacn's mom says this is all a miracle; thank you for helping us prove her right!  So there's yet another benefit to this - his mom's going to make triply sure Yacn achieves all his dreams!

Other ways you can help:

There's more than one way you can help us with this.  Yes, even just $5 is amazing, but there are also ways that won't cost a dime:  

  • Spread the word!  Share this story with your friends via email, Facebook, Twitter, TomTom - anything will do!  Tell your classmates, your family, your soccer team, your church - tell everyone!
  • Indiegogo has share tools, too - please share :)

And thank you.  Because of you, miracles do happen.

story:
We invite you to join us on Saturday, April 25th, in a joint effort by the American-Bosnian and Herzegovinian Association of Utah (ABHA) and Bosnian American Professionals Association (BAPA) to raise funds for the BOSANA Foundation. Proceeds will go towards providing scholarship opportunities to students in Bosnia. 


ABHA 3723 South 900 East, SLC UT 

just east of Fat Cats

Time- 7pm

Please join us for a fun night of food, music and dancing, and to learn more about Bosana, its students and programs!

Bosana Foundation provides marginalized youth with the tools, funds and resources to make positive life choices that enable them to maximize their personal potential; therefore, moving them from a predicament of poverty to stability and self-sufficiency, which promotes viable civil societies. We hope that through the empowerment and education of youth history does not repeat itself and that Bosnia and Herzegovina can once again be a country that boasts peaceful multi-ethnic and multi-cultural traditions.

Pozivamo Vas da nam se pridruzite u subotu, 25.tog aprila u zajedničkom trudu ABHA-e i BAPA-e u prikupljanju donacija za BOSANA Fondaciju. Doniranih sredstava će ići za svrhe stipendiranja studenata u Bosni i Hercegovini. 

Molimo Vas da nam se pridruzite i ovom prilikom saznate više o Bosani, te njenim studentima i programima uz hranu, muziku i dobru zabavu!

story:
Short Summary

We are a diverse group of Novocastrians (and Lake Macquarians!) who came together to plan something positive and wonderful for our community. We wanted an event that was a celebration of our culturally and religiously diverse community. A celebration of the human race! We formed the group, Newcastle: Unity in Diversity, and have teamed up with Refugee Action Network Newcastle to plan this festival as part of National Refugee Week.

Our group came together in response to the racism and bigotry of the Reclaim Australia movement. We felt we couldn't stand by and do nothing in the face of the lies and myths being spread about Muslim people. We believe in the old saying that 'for evil to prevail, all it takes is for good men (and women) to do nothing'. So we are doing something!

The festival starts at the Newcastle Museum at 11am on Saturday 13 June 2015.  We then walk to Civic Park, Newcastle where we start with an Awabakal smoking ceremony and Welcome to Country.  Following this there will be speakers from the Christian (Fr Rod Bower from the Gosford Anglican Church), Muslim, and Jewish congregations.  We have food stalls, bands and dancers. Face painting, hair braiding and much more! It will be a family day so bring your picnic rugs and settle in for an afternoon of multicultural entertainment.

We feel this festival is incredibly important. It creates the opportunity for all those people who want to contribute to making our world a better place, to stand together. The festival will be a celebration but it is also a 'push back' against the racism, hate and bigotry.

Find us on Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/events/804117496304858/

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding for some of the performers, the printing of banners and posters, and the stage and PA hire. All up our costs are currently around $3,700 which we are using our own credit cards for!

As we are a really grassroots community group we don't really have any perks or rewards to offer you, just a better, happier and safer world to live in! We will be posting all contributors' names on our FaceBook page and we'll read out a list at the festival.

story:
For the past 10 years the partnership between Performing Stars in Marin City and Sailing Education Adventures in San Rafael has been going strong. The program takes students ages 9-15 form Marin City and provides to them a no- cost way to get out on the water and learn to sail! 


We have been able to provide this opportunity to students who may not otherwise have the opportunity to attend camp through the generosity of a local sponsor (until now). 

Our program is scheduled for July 13-17, 2015 and our normal sponsor cannot continue to support the program this year. We NEED your help!

What We Need 

Cost breakdown: 
Each student costs $200 to attend the week long camp
  • this cost includes insurance, counselor/instructor expenses, use of the marina and the boats.
Lunches for each student cost $15 per day approximately
  • typically lunches are sourced from local groceries or restaurants and delivered by volunteers who support the program.

Anything that you can contribute will help give one of these students an amazing experience that will help transform their lives. 

The Importance of this Program

Details:
12 students from Marin City
A one week camp which teaches students
  • sailing terms and techniques
  • wind direction, steering and points of sail
  • teamwork
  • problem solving
  • leadership
  • independence
  • self-confidence 
  • environmental awareness
  • and many useful real world skills

Students also make new friends and learn about something brand new to them. So often students from Marin City would not have this opportunity if not for this camp. This camp provides not just lessons in sailing but also important lessons in life. Sailing has the power to transform lives and that is what we aim to do each year with this successful and proven camp. 

In addition to this opportunity, students have the opportunity to continue sailing with our program if they are interested through scholarships. Continuing sailing gives students an outlet and a pathway with real world skills that can translate into employment with our own organization or with other sailing programs around the bay or around the country. 


Be a Star, help Performing Stars send their students to Sail Camp!


Risks & Challenges

With our short time frame we realize that we might not raise the full amount that it takes to make this camp happen. Our non- profit is willing to take a loss on this program just to ensure that this important program continues, however our margins are already very tight. We hope that through some of our members and community partners that we can reach and exceed our goal. Any excess funds will go towards our scholarship program for these students who wish to continue sailing. 

Perks

We would like to offer more for your generous donation however we can only do so much for our wonderful donors. We will however be sending hand written letters to some of our valued donors as well as providing updates with pictures of the camp daily so you can see the happy faces of the students. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give money, please share our campaign to your social network. You can also help by providing lunch for one or more of the days and helping with logistics for the camp. Please contact programdirector@sfsailing.org if you have any questions.

story:
Buket'i New York'taki oyunculuk eğitimi için destekleyin!

(scroll down for English)

Merhaba! Ben Buket. 

Karşıma çıkan her türlü zorluğa rağmen inandığım şeyin peşinden yıllarca koştum ve The Actors Studio Drama School'dan oyunculuk yüksek lisansı için kabul alarak hayalime bir adım daha yaklaştım.


Hayalim mümkün olan en iyi oyunculuk eğitimini alabilmekti ve  kendi kendime oyunlar okuyup onların içinden bir monolog seçtim. The Actors Studio Drama School'a başvurmak için bir dakikalık bir video hazırladım. Marlon Brando, Jane Fonda, Al Pacino, Bradley Cooper gibi dünyaca ünlü oyuncuların yetiştiği The Actors Studio Drama School'a kabul edilen öğrenciler arasından bu yıl Türkiye'den giden tek öğrenci olacağım. Okul tarafından The President's Graduate yetenek bursu ile ödüllendirilmeme rağmen geri kalan ücreti ödemek için imkanlarım çok yetersiz. 
Maddi destek için kime danıştıysam bana Türkiye'den bir şey umut etmememi söyledi. Bunun bir önyargı olduğunu düşünüp uzanabildiğim her kuruma, vakıfa ve şirkete gidip durumumu anlattım. Güzel ve yeterli birçok yurtdışı eğitim bursu bulunmakta ancak söz konusu sahne sanatları olduğunda durum biraz değişiyor. Sanat bursu verdiğini söyleyen bazı kurumlar var ancak onlar da oyunculuğu bunun içine dahil etmiyor ya da lisansta sanat eğitimi almış olma şartı koşuyor. Durum böyle olunca, ben de bu durumu kendi deneyimim üzerinden sorunsallaştırmak istedim. Sadece kendim için değil, bunun bir devamlılık olması için de sesimi duyurup sahne sanatları alanında yurtdışında eğitim alacak öğrencilere bir burs imkanı yaratmak için uğraşıyorum. Yurtdışı olmasının bir önemli sebebi de özellikle Amerika'da okuyacak öğrencilerin çalışma izinlerinin olmamasından kaynaklanıyor.
Ben bu kadar umutlanmışken vazgeçmek istemiyorum, eğer kampanyamı paylaşmama yardım ederseniz bu benim için çok büyük bir motivasyon ve umut olacak. Şimdiden çok teşekkür ederim.
 

Eğitim Hayatım 

2005-2009 yılları arasında Bornova Anadolu Lisesi'nde okudum. 2009 yılında Boğaziçi Üniversitesi Matematik Bölümü'nde üniversite eğitimime başladım. 2012 yılında Matematik Bölümü'nde okumaya devam ederken tekrar ÖSS'ye girdim ve güzel bir dereceyle Boğaziçi Üniversitesi Felsefe Bölümü'nü kazandım.  Bölümü üç yıl içinde tamamlayarak bu haziranda 3.50 not ortalamasıyla mezun olacağım. 

Son altı yılda oyuncu olarak yer aldığım projelerden bazıları:

Onikinci Gece - Bornova Anadolu Lisesi Oyuncuları, Izmir (2008)

Lysistrata - Boğaziçi Üniversitesi Oyuncuları, İstanbul (2009)

Kadınlar Meclisi - Boğaziçi Üniversitesi Oyuncuları, İstanbul (2010)

Pinocchio - Studententheater De Koffer, Tilburg Üniversitesi, Hollanda (2013):
Bu oyun ile ilk kez uluslararası bir tiyatro topluluğuyla çalışma fırsatını elde ettim. Pinokyo masalını günümüze uyarlayan Rudolf van Bree yönetiminde müzikli bir oyun hazırlayıp şehrin tiyatro merkezinde sergiledik.

Bugün Çok Güzel Görünüyorsun - Zürih Güzel Sanatlar Üniversitesi desteğiyle, İstanbul (2014): 
Bea Schild'in yüksek lisans bitirme projesi olan bu çalışma Zürih Güzel Sanatlar Üniversitesi desteğiyle İstanbul'da gerçekleşti. Ben dahil dört performansçının yer aldığı, herkesin bireysel hikayelerinden ve yaptığı röportajlardan yola çıkarak oluşturduğu sahne parçalarıyla oluşan bu performans kültür ve cinsiyet arasındaki ilişkiyi kıyafetler ve nasıl giyindiğimiz üzerinden deneysel bir şekilde anlatıyor. Galata'daki giysi dükkanı Bin Bavul'da sergilenen bu performansın hazırlık sürecinde Liliana Heimberg ile çalışma fırsatını elde etmiş oldum.





****************************



Support Buket in her Acting MFA at The Actors Studio Drama School in New York!


Hello! I'm Buket.


I have been chasing my dream despite of all the things I have been through in life and I recently received acceptance from The Actors Studio Drama School for a MFA in Acting. Finally, I am moving one step closer to my dream!

It was my goal to receive a decent education and I have prepared for auditions by myself. I read lots of plays and chose one monologue from among them. I shot a one-minute video which I submitted to apply to The Actors Studio Drama School. It is an inexpressible feeling for me to be accepted to this unique school as the only Turkish student this year, which has many notable alumni like Marlon Brando, Jane Fonda, Al Pacino, and Bradley Cooper. Also, I have been offered the President's Graduate Scholarship which is equal to one fourth of the tuition. However, I am not able to cover the rest of the expenses. 
Unfortunately, it is difficult to find support for art and arts education in Turkey. Everybody I consult about scholarships says it is better not to lay hopes on Turkey in this regard. First, I thought this was just a case of prejudice and I applied to every foundation and company that offers scholarships for graduate education. But in the end I have learned is that though there are several scholarships in existence, these are allocated to students who will have “convenient vocations” after their education. In other words, if I were to get a diploma to work in a company after my graduate study, I could find a scholarship. Still, there are some foundations which claim that they offer a scholarship for education in the arts but most of them exclude acting or they decline my application because I am not graduated from a conservatory. Since this is the case, I decided to take action by using my personal experience to draw attention to this issue. I am trying to make this problem visible both for myself and other students who will receive an arts education abroad. My goal is to convince some foundations or institutions to offer an ongoing arts scholarship. The reason this scholarship is necessary for education in the arts abroad, specifically, is that work permits for foreign students, especially in The United States are not possible.

I do not want to give up hope when I am this close to my dream. If you help me to share the word through my campaign, I believe this will show that there are people who are sensitive to this issue. Thank you in advance.


Educational Background 

I am a graduate from a well known high school, Bornova Anatolian High School, in Izmir. I started to study Mathematics in Bogazici University in 2009. My dream has always been my dream, but I have always aimed to be a well-educated actress who can feed her artistic endeavours through various subject matters. I realized my interest in philosophy and began to study Philosophy at Bogazici University in 2012. I have completed my major in three years and in June I will graduate with high honors.  

Theatre projects in which I played a role:

Twelfth Night - Bornova Anatolian High School Players, Izmir (2008)

Lysistrata - Bogazici University Players, Istanbul (2009)

Women in Council - Bogazici University Players, Istanbul (2010)

Pinocchio - Studententheater De Koffer, Tilburg University, Holland (2013):

Through this project, I had the opportunity to work in an international theatre play. Rudolf van Bree, Dutch theatre director, adapted the well-known story of Pinocchio as a musical theatre play and it was performed in the theatre building De NWE Vorst in the city center.

You Look Good Today - Zurich University of the Arts, Istanbul (2014): 

This project was performed in Istanbul with the cooperation of Zurich University of the Arts as the master's project of Bea Schild. I was one of the performers who created the scenes and parts of the performance using our personal stories and interviews we held with several other people. The project questioned the relationship between culture and gender by focusing on clothing and fashion in particular. In the process of preparation for this performance which was performed in a vintage store in Galata, Istanbul, as an actress I had the change to be coached by Liliana Heimberg, actress, drama teacher and director.
story_txt:

story:
Introduction

Salmonberries (Rubus spectabilis) are wild berries native to the beautiful Pacific Northwest and Alaska. This plant has cultural and historical significance for local indigenous tribes. Salmonberries are close relatives of raspberries and blackberries, which are cultivated worldwide. Recently there is an increasing interest in those berries, because they are rich in phytonutrients known for their health benefits. Despite such interesting properties, biologists have not explicitly studied salmonberries. 

We, a group of curious young scientists from high schools of the Seattle area, are raising money to uncover the genetic secrets of salmonberries. With your help, we will be able to perform gene sequencing from multiple tissues of salmonberry.  We have been learning genomic data analysis techniques for the last couple of summers and are now ready to delve into the experience of an original research project that will contribute to the biological understanding of this native plant. 

Why Salmonberry (Rubus spectabilis)?  

In the Pacific Northwest, we have a rich enthnobotany and many native plants with fascinating medical uses. Salmonberry is one such plant. As a member of Rubus genus, it is  related to raspberries, believed to have been brought to North America across the Bering Land Bridge. Blackberries and Finland's popular cloudberries also lie is the same Rubus genus.

Choosing salmonberry lets us ask some intriguing scientific questions and make comparisons with other plants in the same genus, as well as unrelated plants that have medicinal properties. Plus, we love our salmonberries!   

Experimental Design and Objectives

Despite having identical chromsomes, various tissues of a plant (e.g. roots, flowers, fruits) differ from each other, because they have different sets of active genes. Our goal is to find the genes active in various tissues of salmonberries.  To do that, we will extract RNA from roots, stems, leaves and fruits of salmonberry plants, convert each RNA sample into cDNA and send to a sequencing lab.

Once we get the sequencing data back from the lab (usually in the form of a text file), we will begin to computationally analyze it to figure out what exactly is happening within the tissues of salmonberry. We will be assembling and annotating the transcriptome, which is basically reconstructing the sequences of various genes and their possible functions. One of the ways this is done is by comparing the sequence with an entire database of genes and proteins (NCBI BLAST), whose locations (and for many, also the functions) have been identified. Since comparing the sequence with the database indicates other places where the same sequence is found, it is then possible to figure out what the probable function of the sequence is. The sequencing experiment will therefore inform us about the gene sequences of salmonberry, which are currently unknown, and their evolutionary history. 

The sequencing experiment will also allow us to find out which genes are active in the selected tissues of salmonberry. Using computational methods outlined above, we can narrow down what genes we hypothesize to be responsible for the unique properties of the salmonberry, including its medicinal benefits. In addition, utilizing new technologies such as CRISPR, we can even edit the genetic sequence (in a future experiment) to see if our hypotheses actually hold true.

What We Need & What You Get 

While we look forward to  analyzing all the data ourselves, we need to pay a sequencing lab to get the RNA sequencing done using the Illumina technology. We are raising $5000 to cover the cost of sequencing, as well as the RNA extraction experiment and any additional cost of collecting the actual plant samples.  

This project is a unique opportunity for you to contribute to a project conducting original research and also go behind the scene with us to learn about the recent technological advances in genomics. You will join us at our online discussion forum discussing research ideas, and also get early access to public progress reports and insights. If you choose to support our study, we have a range of other incentives including acknowledgement in our paper, invitation to information sessions and one-on-one tutorials. Please check our incentives section on the sidebar for more details.

The Impact 

High schoolers raising money 

The Salmonberry genomics is a research project driven by us, high schoolers under the guidance of knowledgeable advisors.  This high school project uniquely combines scientific research with crowdfunding thus providing our future innovators and scientists a valuable real-world experience of transforming ideas into executable projects.  As part of the process of the launch, we  proposed a streamlined budget,  prepared content and materials for presenting to the donor (the public) for support and learned valuable teamwork balancing our strengths and busy schedules. Your support of this project will insure that this model of entrepreneurial experience can be shared with more high-school students. 

Health Benefit of Berries 

Discoveries that we find with salmonberry will aid the scientific community in extrapolating information on the medicinal benefits of similar plants. The opportunity to study the genetics behind phytonutrients also lies in this project, which would ideally add to our understanding of why these plants have curative benefits.  

Scientific Impact 

In a rapidly advancing world of medicine, it's important to take a step back and realize that mother nature herself contains some of the most potent aids to our health issues. Tapping into this could allow us to uncover more information behind what makes these organisms so clinically important. Coming at this from a genetics point of view, finding what part of the genome accounts for this special property of the salmonberry could give us insight into other plants with medicinal benefits.   

We will spread genomic education 

The public understanding of "what is genomic or genetic data" and how that data may provide insights into biology, ancestry or health is fundamentally important.  Today there is a race to develop and market direct-to-consumer genetic tests related to health and wellness. The reports from such tests are little understood by the consumer.   As our lives become more integrated with personal genomic information, high schoolers like us can be the leaders in the genomic education of the public.  Projects such as the salmonberry genomics are the instruments to technically train the high schoolers in genomic data.   Then these young students can share the knowledge widely, where they live as well as online. 

Risks & Challenges

Though sequencing and computational analyses of other berries have been performed in the past, none have been done for salmonberry. This being our first hands-on project as a group poses its own challenges. We are excited to use our newly acquired knowledge in the field of bioinformatics for a hands-on project with the guidance of our well-experienced advisors. You can meet our advisors and rest of us here.

Wish us luck! 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you are unable to donate to our project, please help us out to spread the message around!

story:
Hallå!

 

Thank you for stopping by! I'll be embarking on my second study abroad journey in just 3 short weeks to Växjö, Sweden. There, I will be studying design at Linnæus University. Of course I am WAY excited, and I have been working hard to get to this point! While working 3 jobs and going to school full time, I have been saving my pennies for this huge adventure ( after all, Sweden is a pretty dang expensive place ).

 

 I've had a few family members / friends from out of town ask if I had a fundraiser page for this trip ( like I did my last ), so this a a place where they can support me if they choose!

 

Thanks for your support!

Thanks for your support!

story:
I am a first generation student attending Hamline University. I'm a second year that has declared a major in Anthropology (focus on cultural anthro) and I'm still deciding on a double major (environmental studies, education, or criminal justice.) I am involved on campus with different orgs like HALO (Latinx Org) and a New Student Mentor, Catalyst Leader, etc. 
Money has been tight all school year since there are 2 of us from my family attending college now. This semester has been one the hardest semester mentally and financially. I'm currently working as an after school teacher at two different sites. I teach about STEM through a social justice perspective. The program I'm with empowers youth of color to change our world through science. However, this job is BARELY enough to pay my rent, let alone help me pay for school. 
I also do some work around the Twin Cities related to racial justice, environmental justice, and youth empowerment. 

My school's financial aid has not been the best help - I filled out the loan for the amount they gave me and that is not enough due to other things that they did not tell me. I just found that out today. I have not registered for any classes so as of right now, I am not a student for next semester. A few of the classes I need to take have already been filled up due to them not letting me register. Since I just found out just a few hours ago, I'm stressed out. I'm leaving the country on Thursday morning up until the end of the month. I will have limited internet access so I am not able to figure this out during my time out. I need to figure it out by tomorrow or I will not be able to take a winter course - which I NEED if I'm going to double major.  This is also the last year that Hamline is offering a "free" winter course - I need to take advantage of it. If I don't figure this out before I leave, I will not be doing a winter course which messes up credits, and I don't know if I'll be able to attend spring semester. 

I would appreciate any help that I could get.

story:
OUR PERKS

​In addition to guitar pics, stickers, teeshirts, and hoodies, we have a special perk for the David Bowie fans out there. Scout Bookham is a 9-year old guitarist who has been taking lessons at MCMA for 4 years. Her idol is David Bowie, and when he passed away, Scout decided to raise $1,500 in his honor for a memorial scholarship. Scout has a number of Bowie inspired posters that she has designed this fall, and in exchange for a $50 donation to her scholarship fund, she will send you a signed poster. For those of you in the area, come to our winter student recital on January 29th at the Strand Theater to hear Scout play "Space Oddity" and announce the results of her fundraising effort.

story:
WHO AM I

•I am a transdisciplinary* artist who discovered it is possible to
photograph water as it creates magical images. This was known as
scrying and was dismissed as a superstition in the last centuries
because it could not be proven. However, new technologies prove that
water does indeed speak to us in a beautiful and complex visual
language. I call my practice Emerge Art. I have been blogging for many
years, I am an internationally read blogger: http://thelenaghioparadox.blogspot.com 

You can verify the evolution of Emerge Art through all the
articles listed on this page:  Emerge Art Origins,  that demonstrate my reasoning process as I
photographed and investigated the hidden behavior of nature.

I want to produce this illustrated book so people will know about this feature
of nature that was well known by our ancestors.

* «Transdisciplinary
Art is art which uses transdisciplinary research and methods to
explore a problem of humanitarian concern… addressing an artistic
problem which exists outside the scope of the disciplines and methods
used to explore it.» https://transdisciplinaryart.wordpress.com/

WHY IS THIS PROJECT IMPORTANT

•Emerge Art is the true language of water. In this book I will display
evidence of the authenticity of this statement, look at the wide
ranging history of scrying and its important role in the intellectual
and spiritual evolution of mankind. It is NOT supernatural, it is natural if rare. I will illustrate its simplicity through the stories water told me in images. Our life source is speaking to us and we now have the means to hear it. What could be more important? I am passionate because it
is so moving to see these magnificent images that always take me aback. It is our common planetary truth, the one thing that makes our journey in the cosmos brilliant and unique. Our watery planet is totally vibrantly alive and sentient.


WHAT YOU WILL HELP ME ACHIEVE

• With Emerge Art I can share the uncanny creative force of nature
that defies logic and make it genuine. With this project we will make
a foundation that will allow new fields of research to come out of the
documented phenomena. This could include new technologies like
Artificial Intelligence. The success of the fundraiser and of the book
will give me the funds to invite professional collaborators in future
investigation of this untapped potential.

WHAT I NEED

•I am asking for 25000$. That is the amount I calculated for the
editing, printing and marketing of a deluxe illustrated book. I will
produce a book you will be proud to have your name in.

WHAT YOU WILL GET


Emerge Art will make you experience the feeling of wonder itself, the thrill of communion, the gentle touch of connectedness with all that surrounds us.
You will renew this experience every time you look through the images.
The Language of Water will be an illustrated book that will contain
high quality prints of the most astonishing manifestations, a basic
methodology for the results I have obtained so far and the stories
water told me when I asked questions like: Who is Jesus of Nazareth?
Who is the Nagual Don Juan Matus? Who was the sorcerer teacher of the
famous writer Carlos Castaneda. Who is Joan of Arc?


RISKS & CHALLENGES

If I don’t reach the entire fundraising goal, I will still use whatever
I get to pursue this worthwhile objective.

My work is unique, honest and universal. Everyday the number of people
reading about and enjoying Emerge Art articles on my blog increases.
(Emerge Art Origins) People from around the world resonate with this
discovery that will answer many questions that have haunted humanity
since the beginning.


EACH CONTRIBUTION COUNTS

Big or small, money or simply sharing the campaign with others, EVERY contribution counts counts!
I will keep you updated on all progress, news, and breakthroughs on my blog: http://thelenaghioparadox.blogspot.com as I consolidate the relationships with the collaborators who will make this project as excellent as we all deserve. The Indigogo tools will
make the sharing easy.

GRATITUDE

story:
I got accepted to attend Manhattan Christian College in Manhattan Kansas for this year. I will be studying Ministry with my major being in Bible and Leadership Or Christian Ministry with an emphasis in Children's/Family Ministry. I will be attending MCC this upcoming Fall 2014 (Last Day in Arizona is 8/19, leave 8/20th.) My campaign though is to help raise money to help pay for my Room/Board (Includes Meal plan too), that is all that I have left. This will help me pay for the rest of my college money that I owe. So my main goal is to raise as much as possible for my Room/Board money to be complete or some of it paid for.  This is my dream school and I am super Blessed to have gotten accepted and can't wait to go!!!!!!

Philippians 4:13- "I CAN DO ALL THINGS THROUGH CHRIST WHO GIVES ME STRENGTH"

I appreciate ALL prayers too please, very much so!! : )
(Attached on you tube is one of my favorite songs and has encouraged me to choose this school and go for it, helped to call me into this.) Reason being is because in the lyrics it says,
"Spirit lead me where my trust is without borders
Let me walk upon the waters
Wherever You would call me
Take me deeper than my feet could ever wander
And my faith will be made stronger
In the presence of my Savior"
-To me that is talking about me going out into another state and adventuring out and putting all of my Trust and Faith in God and know He will get me through everything! There is so much more to this song, but the majority of it is Trusting God and Growing in Him.
Thanks and God Bless,
Zach Price

story:
Has this happened to you?

Have you ever experienced frustration trying to find biblically based children’s books? Have children ever lost interest as you read the Bible to them?  If you can relate, then we are asking you to support a solution to these challenges – 

the Big Chair Bible!


The Inspiration...

When author/illustrator Adrian Harris' three daughters were small, he experienced this dilemma firsthand.  When he read secular books to his daughters – with catchy rhymes and colorful pictures (especially those written by a famous Dr.) – they were mesmerized and begged for more. But when he pulled out the Bible or children's books based on Biblical themes, they lost interest and quickly climbed down from the family's “big chair.” That is why he decided to create the Big Chair Bible series.


Why we feel this is so important...

Through colorful images and limerick, The Big Chair Bible is a powerful tool to assist families and Christian educators in sharing God's Word with young minds and hearts. The first book in the series is David vs. Goliath and tells one of the greatest accounts of heroism and faith ever told! More importantly, the story narrative is a faithful representation of the Biblical passage I Samuel 17:1-58, and is written in a way that is developmentally appropriate for children. 


Why we need your help...

To date, this project has been funded by Adrian, with support from a few generous family members and friends. But to bring the book to fruition, additional funding is needed for equipment, materials, and printing.  We need your support to get this valuable teaching tool into the hands of parents, grandparents, educators, and most importantly OUR CHILDREN! 

Will you join us in this effort to create a tool to impact the spiritual lives of children by equipping  families and educators for engaging Bible study?

story:
Thank you to everyone who helped me hop aboard the Millennial Train! I could not have done this without every single one of you and am looking forward to sharing the journey. Follow me on: 

Instagram 

Twitter

Snapchat 

for photos, video and snaps as we explore cities across the country! 

THE MILLENNIAL TRAINS PROJECT (MTP) is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that leads crowd-funded transcontinental train journeys for diverse groups of young innovators (and virtual audiences) to explore America's new frontiers.

To get on board, applicants design a project to advance across the communities where our train stops and then race to be among the first 15 applicants on their selected train journey to reach their $5,000 crowdfunding goal. To learn more about the 2016 journeys click here. The applicant's project is described below.

 

The What 

What is the purpose of school in the 21st century?

Teachers and students lack a proper platform to dissect this essential question within their communities, as well as online. The Millennial Teacher in Motion (that's me!) will kickstart these conversations in cities like Los Angeles, San Francisco, Denver, Milwaukee and Detroit. My project will examine the dynamic lives of Millennial teachers and their students through in-person interviews which ask them a variety of questions, namely: 

- What initially attracted you to the teaching profession? 

 

- What is making you stay in the classroom?

And the most essential question: 

 

- What do you believe is the purpose of school in the 21st century?

There is a sense of urgency to my project because if the United States wants to recruit the best and brightest minds to enter and stay in the classroom, I believe it must reimagine how it incentivizes future would-be career teachers to join the field of education and how it equips students with the 21st century skills needed to succeed in a globalized idea economy.

Whoa, whoa, whoa. Okay, let's back up a bit and start at the beginning. My journey to the classroom is a bit of an alternative one. After realizing I enjoyed volunteering to teach English to adult immigrants in the District way more than working at my salaried day job, I hightailed it down to South America where I fell in love with the beauty and spirit of Colombia. While there, I worked in support of the National Ministry of Education's bilingualism initiative. Upon my return to the States, I applied to an alternative teacher certification program which placed me in the high school I now work. I teach high school English and am grateful for the fact that no day in the classroom is ever the same. Ever.

 

Media Técnica students in Neiva - Huila, Colombia

But one question I constantly ask myself while teaching is: what is the purpose of school? Why do my students spend hours and hours shuffling between different rooms to learn about different subjects while constantly being controlled by a bell? How am I preparing them to enter a global workforce that requires them to think critically across all content areas, communicate effectively and be empowered, open-minded, passionate individuals? That's a toughie. It's a question I also think several Millennial teachers and their students ask themselves regularly too which is why I want to engage with them in the first place! 

The Dollars & Sense 

I need to crowdsource $5,000 to join my fellow Millennials on a transcendental train trip across the country with Millennial Trains Project (MTP). MTP conducts a weeklong, 3,000 mile journey from coast to coast for members of Generation Y to collaborate, engage, reflect and kickstart their diverse projects along the way. While aboard, we will meet with some incredible community members; from business leaders and government officials, to tech entrepreneurs, artists and modern changemakers. 

 

 

Practicing for MTP in my head: "All aboard!" 

In partnership with MTP, I hope to travel across the country this summer to sit down with teachers and students alike in cities like Los Angeles, San Francisco, Denver, Milwaukee and Detroit to have an honest conversation not just about what they think the purpose of school is, but to hear where they think the future of school is headed. Video and photographs of the interviews will be published on my blog and social media platforms like Twitter, Periscope and Instagram. This venture - StoryCorps meets MTV’s Real World confessional booth - will offer first-hand teacher and student accounts and recommendations about how to go about reimagining the purpose of school in America. Once we've pulled into our final destination, I will curate, synthesize and present the interviews’ contents to graduate schools of education, alternative teacher certification programs, the US Department of Education and school districts nationwide. What’s more, I am Institutional Review Board (IRB) certified and already have experience organizing, recording and publishing multilingual student interviews with support from a university grant when I was an undergraduate student. That blog can be accessed here. 

What I am most looking forward to about the interview process is having an honest conversation not just about what Millennial teachers think the purpose of school is, but hear where they think the future of school is destined. Will students still be sitting in rows and learning individual subjects one room at a time (like they have for the past 125 years) come 5, 10 or 15 years from now? Will credits in a given subject be tied to how many hours a student's behind has been in a chair in that row? Will they still be demonstrating their learning by bubbling in A, B, C or D?

If the United States wants to recruit the best and brightest minds to enter the teaching workforce, how is it incentivizing future would-be teachers to join the field of education instead of becoming highly-paid computer programmers, business consultants or marketing gurus? 

 

 

Still not convinced? Well, in the case that I am unable to fundraise the entire amount, your donation will be returned in full. It's all or nothing, people! 

The Impact

    Your contribution will help support the growing conversation about the true purpose of school in today's innovation economy where young people will be compensated for their ideas while working at jobs that mostly do not exist yet. Yeah, that's right, according to futurist Thomas Frey, 2 billion of the jobs that exist today will be gone by 2030. That's billion with a B. And considering President Obama just announced a proposal to devote $4 billion to computer science education for all children, grades K-12, over the next three years, it's safe to say that the traditional model of education will have to evolve if it's going to meet the needs of our new, tech-centric economy. 
    So, what is the purpose of school in the 21st century? 
    While this essential question has millions of possible answers, I believe it is vital that us Millennial teachers sit down with one another and our students to break down the true purpose of school -both now and in the future- if we are to continue to serve and grow as professional educators who help students cultivate the skills and knowledge they will need to be successful so that they can become the next global systems architects, inflectionists, data contextualists and 3dimensionalists. You can individually Google those bad boys or you can just click here.  

    Whatever you do, do it with love (graffiti from one of the high schools in Colombia)
    The Risks & Challenges
      While the cost of the MTP ticket is substantial, I am confident that the results and recommendations of the Millennial teacher interviews will prove valuable to both organizations and individuals, whether to teacher training programs like the one I am studying in now with Johns Hopkins University or to governmental organizations like the US Department of Education. Further, I already have experience successfully crowdsourcing educational projects totaling almost $1,000 with DonorsChoose.org. You can learn more about my funded projects here. 

      Will students still be learning individual subjects one room at a time a decade from now? Will credits in a given subject be tied to how many hours a student's behind has been in a chair? Will they still be demonstrating their learning via standardized tests? My interviews will begin to  reimagine the purpose of school one teacher, student and city at a time. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you just cannot part with your cold hard cash, no worries. You can still help!

      • Phone/text a friend: get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
      • Share my campaign's project page using the Indiegogo share tools!
      • Follow me on Twitter and Instagram! 
      And thank you for your time and consideration, I sincerely appreciate it. 
      All aboard! 
      The Millennial Teacher in Motion 
      Note:
      If my campaign is among the first 15 to reach its $5,000 goal, all funds raised will go to MTP, which is a 501(c)3 organization. As such, they will be tax-deductible. These funds help to underwrite the costs of the journey and its associated programming, transportation, and hospitality costs. If I am not among the first 15 applicants to reach their crowdfunding goal, none of my supporters will be charged.

Will students still be sitting in rows and learning individual subjects one room at a time (like they have for the past 125 years) come 5, 10 or 15 years from now? Will credits in a given subject be tied to how many hours a student's behind has been in a chair in that row? Will they still be demonstrating their learning by bubbling in A, B, C or D?
If the United States wants to recruit the best and brightest minds to enter the teaching workforce, how is it incentivizing future would-be teachers to join the field of education instead of becoming highly-paid computer programmers, business consultants or marketing gurus? 
 
 Still not convinced? Well, in the case that I am unable to fundraise the entire amount, your donation will be returned in full. It's all or nothing, people! 

The Impact

Your contribution will help support the growing conversation about the true purpose of school in today's innovation economy where young people will be compensated for their ideas while working at jobs that mostly do not exist yet. Yeah, that's right, according to futurist Thomas Frey, 2 billion of the jobs that exist today will be gone by 2030. That's billion with a B. And considering President Obama just announced a proposal to devote $4 billion to computer science education for all children, grades K-12, over the next three years, it's safe to say that the traditional model of education will have to evolve if it's going to meet the needs of our new, tech-centric economy. 

So, what is the purpose of school in the 21st century? 
While this essential question has millions of possible answers, I believe it is vital that us Millennial teachers sit down with one another and our students to break down the true purpose of school -both now and in the future- if we are to continue to serve and grow as professional educators who help students cultivate the skills and knowledge they will need to be successful so that they can become the next global systems architects, inflectionists, data contextualists and 3dimensionalists. You can individually Google those bad boys or you can just click here.  


Whatever you do, do it with love (graffiti from one of the high schools in Colombia)

The Risks & Challenges


While the cost of the MTP ticket is substantial, I am confident that the results and recommendations of the Millennial teacher interviews will prove valuable to both organizations and individuals, whether to teacher training programs like the one I am studying in now with Johns Hopkins University or to governmental organizations like the US Department of Education. Further, I already have experience successfully crowdsourcing educational projects totaling almost $1,000 with DonorsChoose.org. You can learn more about my funded projects here. 



Will students still be learning individual subjects one room at a time a decade from now? Will credits in a given subject be tied to how many hours a student's behind has been in a chair? Will they still be demonstrating their learning via standardized tests? My interviews will begin to  reimagine the purpose of school one teacher, student and city at a time. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you just cannot part with your cold hard cash, no worries. You can still help!

Phone/text a friend: get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
Share my campaign's project page using the Indiegogo share tools!
Follow me on Twitter and Instagram! 

And thank you for your time and consideration, I sincerely appreciate it. 
All aboard! 
The Millennial Teacher in Motion 
Note:
If my campaign is among the first 15 to reach its $5,000 goal, all funds raised will go to MTP, which is a 501(c)3 organization. As such, they will be tax-deductible. These funds help to underwrite the costs of the journey and its associated programming, transportation, and hospitality costs. If I am not among the first 15 applicants to reach their crowdfunding goal, none of my supporters will be charged.

story:
Wilderness Inquiry’s Canoemobile is on a mission to change lives of youth – one paddle at a time.

On September 15, we’re rolling into Michigan City, IN as a stop on our national Canoemobile tour. In five days, we plan to take over 500 local kids on paddling and outdoor educational adventures, and we need just $5,000 to make it happen. 

Your support will… 

   • Provide opportunities for youth to experience their local waterway.

   • Connect participants to the outdoors.

   • Inspire a passion for outdoor recreation.

   • Combat issues such as Nature Deficit Disorder, obesity, & the achievement gap.

   • Offer a MEMORABLE experience! 

We are fortunate to work with many generous partners and donors, but we need your help to reach our final goal and make the Michigan City Canoemobile a success! We seek to raise $5,000 to support Canoemobile programming in Michigan City. This money will go towards costs associated with travel, staff, lodging, equipment, permits, and ULTIMATELY, will support Michigan City youth to participate in this valuable experience.

We are creating the next generation of environmental stewards. As more youth grow up in urban areas, their opportunities for outdoor experiences are dwindling. We need to reverse the trend of today’s youth being disconnected from the natural world. 

Studies have shown that direct experiences in the outdoors have the potential to increase community engagement, develop personal skills, increase health, and boost academic achievement. 

With the Canoemobile comes one van, a trailer holding six 24' Voyageur canoes, all gear and equipment, and a crew of dedicated outdoor educators. We are traveling across America bringing dynamic outdoor learning experiences to communities, challenging the notion that outdoor adventure can only happen outside our modern cities. The outdoors is all around us! 

On September 14, the Canoemobile will travel 471 miles from Minneapolis, MN to Michigan City, IN for five days of outdoor adventures on Trail Creek, a tributary of Lake Michigan. In those five days, we will: 

   • Discuss the importance of preserving local waterways.

   • Expose over 500 people to the wilderness of Trail Creek and Lake Michigan.

   • Teach basic paddling and water safety skills.

   • Discuss native and invasive species.

   • Initiate team-building.

   • Canoe, of course!

We have teamed up with local partners to take youth outside for applied learning experiences throughout the week. Not only will youth learn something new, but they will challenge themselves, step out of their comfort zones, and have a blast while doing it! Our trip to Michigan City culminates with a day of paddling open to all members of the community. 


  • Share our fundraising effort with your friends on social media, through word of mouth, rally a community group, or any way you can spread the word.
  • Follow the Canoemobile journey on its 24-city tour in 2014. #canoemobile 
  • Volunteer at any of our Canoemobile events around the country.
  • Attend one of our Canoemobile community events with your children to experience the excitement first-hand.
  • Tell local community leaders about our program.
  • Participate in a Wilderness Inquiry trip.

ADVENTURE is our medium.
INCLUSION is our method.
INTEGRATION is our mission.

Wilderness Inquiry is a non-profit organization based in Minneapolis, MN that provides outdoor adventure opportunities for people of all ages, backgrounds, and abilities. Since 1978, we have been delivering our mission to connect individuals to nature by serving more than 375,000 people from all fifty sates and throughout the world.

Through the Canoemobile program, Wilderness Inquiry has been able to connect over 10,000 youth with their local waterways in 17 cities. In 2014, we seek to engage 7,500 youth in 24 cities. 


    We appreciate any sort of contribution you can-do for us. We would not be able to serve as many people as we do without people like you! Take a look at our perks as a way for us to THANK YOU for your support!

story:
日本語の説明は下に掲載しています。

Background

50% of the school age going children in Tudor can’t get education because most of their families are poor and are unable to pay since the schools around are too expensive and the other affordable schools are distance away especially for the nursery pupils. Despite the government offering free primary school, other charges like parents teachers association fee, games fee, security fee and examination fee among others tend to keep children out of school especially the one coming from urban  poor families like Tudor.

Tudor is one of the slum settlements that existed in Mombasa, Kenya. There are around 2,000 households and residents’ main occupation is house help of high-end residential next to the slum area. Large part of the residents lives below one dollar a day. 

About the Tudor project

The project is aimed at supporting the renovation of the community center which will be used as an alternative center for learning of the young children. The center is expected to offer education to the pupils at affordable cost. However, the Center still lacks toilet facilities, water supply, chairs, desks and mats that are appropriate for the running of the school.

Challenges

  • High percentage of children is out of school because of other charges demanded by the schools and distance. The cost for nearest primary is Ksh720 per term and nursery Ksh1,000 per term. This has made 70% of nursery aged children and 50% of primary aged children from to stay at home. while other affordable schools are far away.
  • The hall is currently built using dirt which may pose health problem to the children. It is poorly ventilated and dirt floor may lead to respiratory related diseases.
  • Lack of school facilities—there aren’t toilet facilities, water supply, chairs, mats, and shelves in the center which may facilitate the learning process.

Who we are

The project is done in collaboration between Muungano Wa wanavijiji (federation of slum dwellers) and Muungano Support Trust, a local NGO that has existed in Mombasa, Kenya for 20 years. The Mungano Support Trust has supported slum dwellers agitating for provision of better amenities within settlements.We have done an intervention in Tudor building toilet facilities and the community center. Through this intervention of the Tudor, we realized that more than half of the children in this area are out of school and their parents are seriously concerned about their future. These deliberations ignited the need to support the initiative that the community started.

What We Need

We are aiming to raise a minimum of $4,000 to fund renovation of the community center. The money will cover:

  • Building materials (cements, stones, sands, paints, roofing, nail)
  • Doors, windows
  • Hiring skilled person
  • Desks & Chairs (for children & teachers)
The Mungano Support Trust will support in mobilizing and organizing the community during the renovation period in collaboration with the community members. They will also be training the community on management of the project from inception to the point they will be able to properly manage the entire project as a community.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Tell your friends and families about the Tudor project.
    • Share this project with Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and Email.
    • Embed this project in your website or blog by using “Embed” button on this page.
    • Click “Follow” button on this page.

    FAQ

    Q. How does the community school work?

    A. The community school will be managed by the committee of the community through a registered local community organization currently existing the village. The committee will hire the teachers, collect tuition from children, pay salary for teachers, pay school equipment, and do the maintenance of the building. The education of the community school should be followed Kenyan standard. The community will charge a small amount of tuition which majority of the families will be able to afford.

    Q. If you don’t reach the goal, how do you manage the funds?

    A. If we don’t reach the goal, we can still support the renovation. Depending on the amount of funding, we will decide which part of the renovation, can we contribute. For example, if the funding is enough to desks and chairs, our contribution is the provision of desks and chairs.

    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

    このプロジェクトの背景

    ケニアのモンバサというケニア第２の都市にTudorというスラム街があります。このTudorでは約半分の学齢の子ども達が貧困のため学校に通えていません。ケニアでは公立学校は無料なものの、PTA、セキュリティ、テストなど、学費以外の費用を支払う必要があり、この地域の人達にとって支払いが難しいためです。また、このような公立の学校はこの住宅エリアからは遠く、この距離も子ども達を学校から遠ざけている理由の一つです。

    このTudorには2,000の住宅があり、住人の主な職業は、隣接する高級住宅街のハウスヘルパーです。多くの住人は１日１ドル以下で生活しています。

    Tudor プロジェクトについて

    このプロジェクトは、Tudorにあるコミュニティセンターを子ども達が学べる場所になるようリノベーションすることが目的です。またリノベーション後は、この地域の人達でも支払える金額で、子ども達が教育を受ける場を提供する予定です。このコミュニティセンターは、現在トイレはなく、壁も床も塗装されていないため、泥や砂がむき出しです。そのため呼吸器系の健康問題が懸念されます。また子ども達が学ぶための机や椅子も必要です。

    我々について

    このプロジェクトは、Muungano Wa wanavijiji (このスラム街の住民組合)と ケニアのモンバサで約20年間、スラム街の生活の質改善に取り組んできた現地NGOのMuungano Support Trustが共同で行っています。Muungano Support Trustは既に、この地域にこれまでなかったトイレを提供しました。そのトイレ導入の課程で、この地域の約半分の子ども達が学校に通えないことがわかりました。この地域の保護者達は子どもが教育を受けられないことを真剣に悩んでおり、この地域の要望を受けて、このプロジェクトがスタートしました。

    資金の使い道

    このプロジェクトでは最低でも4,000ドルが必要です。資金は以下の用途で使う予定です。

    • 建物の材料（セメント、石、砂、塗料、屋根、くぎ等）
    • ドア、窓
    • 熟練工の雇用
    • 生徒と教師の机と椅子

    Muungano Support TrustはTudorの人々と恊働し、コミュニティの人々に対して、このリノベーションの工程全体をすすめるためのトレーニングを行います。

    FAQ

    Q. コミュニティスクールとはどのようなものですか？

    A. コミュニティスクールはTudorに住むの人々で構成された実行委員会によって運営される予定です。この実行委員会は教師をやとい、給与を支払い、ビルのメンテナンスを行うなど、このコミュニティスクールの運営全般を担当します。子ども達は近隣の公立学校よりも低い費用でこのコミュニティスクールに通うことができます。

    Q.もし、金額が達成できなかった場合、集めたお金はどのように利用する予定ですか？

    A.もし、達成できなかったとしても、リノベーションをサポートする目的で利用することは変わりません。集まった金額により、どのような貢献ができるかを決めます。例えば、もし集まった金額が、椅子と机を購入できる費用であれば、椅子と机の購入費用に使います。

story:
Summary

***Dates have been set to build the computer lab!!  Help us raise the final $6000 to send the team to Africa in January 2015!!!

Impacting the Next Generation Project (ITNGP) is a non-profit 501(c)(3) that has partnered with Gospelink in Zambia, Africa to help provide a computer lab and computer education to the students attending the International Bible College of Zambia.  These students have had LIMITED or NO exposure to computer training throughout their life. Through a computer lab and on-going training, the project will help them become computer proficient - a vital skill needed for success in today's technology-driven society. This will help position them for success and start to impact generations to come. 

What is the issue, problem, or challenge? 

This project will help start to eradicate the problem of computer illiteracy. Through the computers and provided training, the beneficiaries will learn how to use a computer extensively, opening them up to new employment and business opportunities. This training will help bridge the Digital Divide and the opportunity gap. The educational training will help release their potential and abilities. 

How will this project solve this problem? 

Funds will be used to purchase computers and provide on-going training. This project will provide direct access to computers for use by the students of the college. Access to the computers and training will transform their lives and give them to skills to obtain a better job. 

Potential Long Term Impact 

This training will transform the lives of participants as it will broaden their options and help expose them to new employment and business opportunities. The beneficiaries will become computer literate and proficient - and consequently viable and competitive in the market place. This will help them become independent, self-sufficient and develop their careers. 

Other Ways You Can Help

As you know, every dollar counts!   But if you can't help us with a donation at this time, we ask that you please help us get the word out! Share our campaign with family members, friends, and coworkers.  Thank you!!!

January 2015!!!
